Quote: NEW ZEALAND SAND-FLOUNDER (PATIKI) <i>Rhombosolea plebeia</i> (Richardson) ... The common Sand-flounder is known from one end of New Zealand to the other, sometimes by other names in different localities. In Auckland it is known as the Dab.

Author: DOOGUE & MORELAND

Notes:

Date: 0/0/1967

Author: MORELAND
Vol / Page: 32
Edition:
Quote: SAND FLOUNDER [<i>Rhombosolea plebeia</i>] ... Other names are dab, diamond, tinplate, and square. The Maori name patiki, originally generic, is now loosely used for most flounders.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1970
Source: Nomenclature of NZ Fish
Author: SORENSON
Vol / Page: 24
Edition:
Quote: FLOUNDER (four species) (a) Scientific name: (i) <i>Rhombosolea plebeia(ii) Rhombosolea retiaria (iii)  Rhombosolea tapirina (iv) Rhombosolea leporina.</i> (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: (i) Flounder (ii) Freshwater Flounder (iii) Flounder (iv) Yellowbelly Flounder. (c) Other common names: (i) Square, Dab, Plaice, Diamond or Diamond-back, Tin-plate, Three Corners. (ii) Blacks, Black Flounder (iii) Greenback [25 `Not common but occasionally taken in southernwaters.'] (iv) Yellow Flounder.

Vol / Page: p24
Edition:
Quote: Pureora's endangerd <i>dactylanthus</i> population has a rare claim to fame - it is one of the few sites where another endangered endemic species, the short tailed bat, is known to assist with pollination of the plant. .. <I>Dactylanthus</i> is New Zealand's only completely parasitic plant and grows at several sites in Pureora Forest Park.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1963
Source: In the Sticks
Author: BACON
Vol / Page: 57
Edition:
Quote: It was a small twig, of reddish wood, with three delicately shaped wooden flowers clustered towards the end. They were hard, beautifully fashioned, securely fastened to the stem.  `No, they won't come off,' said Les. `That's dactylanthus;  Dactylanthus Taylori. It's a parasite that gets into the roots of various native trees, usually five finger or lancewood.'
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1984
Source: Some Other Country
Author:
Vol / Page: 78
Edition:
Quote: Cliff was a hard case. He knew lots of yarns too. He'd always start by saying `Did you hear theone about ...?' He didn't seem to like telling them when Norman was there, but he told me some corkers after. He was a real wag. It was good fun going round with him. <i>Ibid</i>. 80 `He's a wag,' said Cliff, `that Johnny Nelson. He's like Hoot Gibson in the pictures.'
Notes: 1950 Gaskell `All Part of the Game' in 1984 Some Other Country 78

Date: 0/0/1951
Source: Personal Communication
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote: She was always told that dag was  Southland rhyming slang for wag, which latter seemed to her mostly used in the North Island at any rate. But the early use (now obs) of Dag! as an expletive (related to Doggon!), from  1917 and Dag at `a dab at' may have some bearing on reinforcement. The probable origin is in EDD n2., v2. 11. a daring feat among boys Ches w Mid w Som: e.g. Som `set a dag: perform some feat in such a way as to challenge imitation ... saying: `There's a dag for you ... do it if you can.'' 12. have or make a dag at `have a shot at'; OED2 sb&sup5. esp.  doing dags, 1879. The earliest non-extant usage may have referred to an event, rather than a person, out of the ordinary, rather than vice-versa as the present evidence might suggest.
Notes: Dental Nurse from Southland

Date: 20/7/2003
Source: Sunday (Sunday Star Times Magazine)
Author:
Vol / Page: 24
Edition:
Quote: Lambie appears, to my homosexual gaze, as a mumsy sort of woman, with the tang of Taranaki about her (I mean here the odour of 'a good sport', 'a dag', with something well-meaning and ingenuous in her manner).
Notes: Original in Landfall, 205 (Wells "Cosmetic..")

Date: 0/0/1987
Source: Boards, Blades & Barebellies
Author: OGONOWSKA-COATES
Vol / Page: 95
Edition:
Quote: Dag. Dried dung hanging from the wool on the sheep's hind legs, under the tail. Cutting this offwith an old pair of shears is called dagging. The dried dags on a sheep make a dry, rattling noise as the sheep runs, hence the term `rattle your dags'.
Notes:

Vol / Page: 15
Edition:

Date: 0/0/1937

Author: PARTRIDGE
Vol / Page: 204
Edition:
Quote: Dag. A `hard case'; a wag; a `character': Australia, thence New  Zealand: from ca, 1890. Prob. ex dagen, q.v. [cant for an artful criminal or near criminal, itself ex cant dagen or degen, a sword]

Date: 0/0/1941
Source: NZ Slang
Author: BAKER
Vol / Page: 51
Edition:
Quote: ... in constant use by our youngsters ... dag. [See also verb, where the implication is that Baker is not familiar with the noun in the sense of `character'.]
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1945
Source: NZ Geographer
Author:
Vol / Page: 19
Edition:
Quote: In the rural districts [of New Zealand] a formidable body of idiomatic uses is developing and a new language is being coined. This isno more true than it is of the `remote' back-country of Canterbury, where changing vocabulary is already a noticable geographical characteristic. The local idiom is naturally often linked with sheep, wool, and station practice. `Dag', for example, is a word used first to describe a tuft of wool fouled by excrement. The removal of dags from the hind-quarters of sheep is a seasonal operation usually called `crutching.' Used personally, `dag' was earlier a term of some approbation.  Its meaning has widened, however, and now signifies no more than `hard case', or `tough guy', or `card.'
Notes: (Cumberland's note to Pascoe's `High Country')

dag

Sense Number:2
Definition:an extraordinary situation or occurrence; esp. what a dag!.
Origin:
Register:

Domain:[none]
Region:[none]

Citations
Date: 0/0/1980
Source: Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A
Author: LELAND
Vol / Page: 31
Edition:
Quote: Dag: literally, this refers to a clot of FECAL MATTER sticking to the tail end of a sheep. It has, however, become part of the language as in `What a dag!' - an admiring statement directed at someone who has done something slightly risque. Some joker threw a pie in the Prime Minister's face, what a dag!

Edition:
Quote: dag NZ & Austral. 1 n. (usu. in pl.) lock of wool clotted with dung on hinder parts of sheep; sl. funny person, a character (he's a bit of a dag). 2 v.t (-gg-)  remove dags from (sheep). 3 dagger 2 person who removes dags from sheep. [Eng. dial.]

dag
Homonym Number: 1
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:A clot of matted wool and excrement hanging from (or cut from) the hindquarters of a sheep. Such daggy wool removed from a sheep; see also sheep-dag.
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:

Date: 7/10/1933
Source: Press, The
Author:
Vol / Page: 15
Edition:
Quote: Dag: Hard or soft dung hanging from the breech of a sheep. Cutting this off the sheep with an old pair of shears is called  dagging. The ds. are afterwards gone through by ad.-picker  or d.-boy, who cuts out any wool worth saving. [c1890-1910].)
Notes: (Acland Gloss.)

Date: 0/0/1946
Source: Some Modern Maoris
Author: BEAGLEHOLE
Vol / Page: 299
Edition:
Quote: Skin colour and the mixture of blood which is responsible for it [sc. high visibility in a white world] are often commented on by one Maori to another. The terms `mongrel', `black mongrel', `dago', or `black nigger', for instance, are often used by Maoris either in referring to themselves or to other Maoris in the neighbourhood. Thus one informant, in introducing herself, remarked: `I'm only a mongrel' - meaning only a mixed-blood Maori.

Date: 0/0/1974
Source: NZ Agriculture
Author:
Vol / Page: 81
Edition:
Quote: `Herringbone' dairies, developed in New Zealand, are increasing rapidly in number. <i>Ibid./</i> 83 The backing gate is used to bring cows from the yard into the dairy. Its main purpose is to keep stock near the milking area. As each cow is taken in to be milked, another fills up the space it has left and there are no delays in milking. The gate is controlled by the milker, who can bring in the next cows without having to leave those already being milked.
Notes:

Source: Settler's Handbook of NZ, The
Author:
Vol / Page: 148
Edition:
Quote: Definition. - A `dairy' is: (a) a milk-house, milk-shop, dairy factory, and any other place wheredairy produce is collected, deposited, treated, separated, prepared, or manufactured, or is sold or offered or exposed for sale; and includes  (b) a farm, stockyard, milking-yard, paddock, stable,stall, and any other place where cows from which the milk-supply of a dairy is obtained are depastured or kept.
Notes: 1898 Dairy Industry Act in 1902 Settler's Handbook of NZ 148

Vol / Page: 4
Edition:
Quote: Specks may also be occasioned by the use of impure salt, which, if it contains lime or free soda, will combine with the butter and make a soap in spots where particles of the salt may have been left undissolved. Using only the best dairy salt, or in case of common salt carefully crushing the salt, mixing it well with the butter, and, after letting it stand for 24 hours, again working and mixing, will prevent it.

Date: 0/0/1900
Source: Canterbury Old & New
Author:
Vol / Page: 188
Edition:
Quote: <Ibid.</i> 210 ... the great Mountain Daisies [fn Celmisias of various species, notably <i>Cel. coriacea</i>.] and other plants which fleck the upland meadows with purest whites and softest yellows ... [<i>Celmisia coriacea</i>] The great white buttercup of the Southern Alps, handsomest of its genus, grows in profusion, only rivalled in beauty by the marguerite-like flowers of the numerous different kinds of `cotton plant' or mountain daisy [fn Species of <I>Celmisia</I>.]. To this assemblage of plants also belong the New Zealand `Edelweiss' [fn <i>Helichrysum grandiceps</i>.] (no mean representative of the Swiss plant [190] from which it derives its name), and the exquisite white-flowered ourisias  [fn <i>Ourisia macrocarpa</i> and <i>macrophylla</i>.], ...

Quote: OXEYE DAISY (Chrysanthemum leucanthemum) ... flower heads about 6cm in diameter with yellow centres, and white rays longer than those of scentless Chamomile or stinking may weed.

Quote: CAPE WEED (<i>Cryptostemma calendulaceum</i> [1967] <i>Calendula</i>) or Cape daisy is abundant in pastures and waste places in the North Island and is also recorded from Greymouth. It is a soft herb, rarely a foot high. ... This weed comes from Cape Colony and so is properly called `Cape Weed'. The same name is given to cats-ear, a much more common weed.

Vol / Page: 9

Quote:  ... the brusquely-interrupted tea and the race over the paddock next to the `Daisy Patch' with one or two of us dropping in the machine-gun fire.
Notes: (Anzac: A Reverie)

Date: 0/0/1988
Source: Voices of Gallipoli
Author: SHADBOLT
Vol / Page: 109
Edition:
Quote: There [on 5 May 1915 in the front line] survivors were ordered to cross an exposed strip of ground, frosted with spring daisies, before [the Turk-held hill] Achi Baba - a place long to be cursed as `The daisy patch'. ... The daisies were soon less conspicuous than the blackening blood of dead and dying New Zealanders as more and more were urged across the open ground. ... After the daisy patch, demoralisation and anger was as rampant among New Zealand officers as among men.
Notes:

Vol / Page: 125
Edition:

Author: PUGSLEY

Dally
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:A Dalmatian (naturalised or born in NZ); earlier Austrian (Northland and Auckland usage chiefly, as Dalmatians settled orig.  on and around the gumfields, and were orig. termedAustrian), cf Scandy.
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:

Author: McGEE
Vol / Page: 40
Edition:
Quote: And dogs, madam, dings dallies dutchies dagoes boongs chinks gooks wogs commies coconuts coons kaffirs pommies polys woollys gollys spics spucs spastics the PYM queers and other long-haired fairies - yes! We love them all!

Date: 0/8/2004
Source: NZ Memories
Author:
Vol / Page: No. 49/48
Edition:
Quote: There was a time when our word was our bond, when you would help your fellow Dally. Why? Because he was <i>Nash</i>... When we visited our relative or friend in hospital we brought them good Dalmatian food, after all, who of the <i>Dallies</i> had a stomach for plain English food? [49] W e all knew who was a <i>Dally</i> - by their faces, real Slavonic and broad, with high cheekbones - by their special walk or gait which went with their breed.

Citations
Date: 0/0/2004
Source: Hooked
Author:
Vol / Page: 204
Edition:
Quote: 'The Dallies don't need a compass,' they'd say. 'All they need is to be able to recognise Rangitoto. They never go out of sight of it.' While there may have been a small amount of truth in the jibe in the 1930s, when the 'Dally fleet' was inclined to be the butt of jokes by other members of the fishing community, it was not the case in the 1940s.

Dally plonk
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:wine made by Dalmatian growers in Henderson, Auckland, formerly sold cheaply at vineyards

Dalmatian
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:an immigrant settler in North Auckland from Dalmatia; one descended from a Dalmatian settler.
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:

Citations
Date: 0/8/2004
Source: NZ Memories
Author:
Vol / Page: No. 49/48
Edition:
Quote: We told everyone that we were Dalmatians and later Yugoslavs and we all stated this with pride - after all, this respect had been earned with much sweat and just as many tears, in the gold fields of the South, on the wild gum fields of the North and in the mountains of Coromandel and in the swamps and drains of the Hauraki Plains. There was a time when the distinction in our community, between a Yugoslav and a Dalmatian was alomost impossible to discern.

Edition:
Quote: Austrian was our first name here and it stuck. But it wasn't the name of a country the New Zealanders invoked when they said it; it was the name of a fear. ... With every shipload ofDalmatians coming to work on the gumfields that fear grew. ... But to my child's mind it was all a confussion - all those names. Austrian. Dalmatian. Some said Croatian. And now Yugoslavs.

dam
Homonym Number: 1
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:In NZ (as in Aust. and Brit. dial.- Sc Yks Derb eAng) the water held back by the barrier, as well as the barrier itself. R Mason notes that one swims in a dam rather than walks on it; and that this has been Auckland usage from c1922.
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:

damper
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number: 1
Definition:a scone or unleavened bread cooked in fat over an open fire or in the coals [ a staple food for early farm and station personnel.]
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:Rural
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/0/1853
Source: Hints to Intending Sheep-Farmers in New Zealand
Author: WELD
Vol / Page: 139
Edition:
Quote: As occasion might offer, he should not think it a degradation, gentleman born though he might be, to heap fresh logs on the fire, put on the soup pot, or to bake a damper in the ashes.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1847
Source: Letters to His Father, 1843-1851
Author: CHAPMAN
Vol / Page: 00
Edition:
Quote: What the host always furnishes is tea (at every meal), damper, i.e. a sort of dough cake baked in the ashes, very good if well made and fried pork.
Notes: Quoted in Miller; Early Victorian NZ, p. 140

Vol / Page: 3
Edition:
Quote: Bread in the shape of a very palatable kind of damper, or unleavened cake, is now an essential part of native food.

Date: 3/10/1846
Source: Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle
Author:
Vol / Page: 123
Edition:
Quote: And weka, uncared for in the settlements! Catch it, as Mrs Glass would say, at Rotoiti or Cape Foulwind; stuff it with sage and onion (for even these condiments accompany the epicurean explorer), roast it on a stick, watch it for half an hour at daybreak, spattering and hissing between you and the fire as you make the damper or pancake, while  your companions are snoring under their blankets around you, and then serve it upon the saucepan lid.
Notes:

Date: 17/3/1855
Source: Lyttelton Times
Author:
Vol / Page: 5
Edition:
Quote: Being regularly knocked up, I meant camping for the night, so I laid down, and took a feed of his damper, mutton, tea and sugar.

Vol / Page: 21

Date: 0/0/1989
Source: Homeplaces
Author: HULME & MORRISON
Vol / Page: 104
Edition:
Quote: Whitebait in pristine condition are beautiful... There are local names for them, too - elephant ears and Dan Doolin 'bait (which isn't true whitebait at all), and cucumbers (which are actually smelt, Retropinna retropinna, or paraki).
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1981
Source: Paparoas Guide
Author: DENNIS
Vol / Page: 189
Edition:
Quote: Tiny, largely transparent bullies are also amongst the migrants ...  common bully (<i>Gobiomorphus cotidianus</i>), redfinned bully (<i>G. huttoni</i>), and bluegilled bully (<i>G. hubbsi</i>). These are sometimes caught in large quantities by whitebaiters. The fishermen call them `Dan Doolin Spawn' or `Whalefeed'.

Date: 0/0/1949
Source: Dictionary of Slang
Author: PARTRIDGE
Vol / Page: 1027
Edition:
Quote: Dance a haka. To exhibit joy, `dance with pleasure': New Zealand  coll.: since ca. 1890. B., 1941. The haka is a Maori ceremonial  dance, wild and impressive. Cf. the Australian corroboree, n. and v.

Date: 0/0/1951
Source: Grasslands of NZ
Author: LEVY
Vol / Page: 134
Edition: 1970
Quote: Many an aspersion is cast at a danthonia knoll waving white with rank growth, and the grass is condemned as being unpalatable, whereas the person casting the aspersion is probably standing on the very same grass eaten down so well that it is to him `English grass'.  ... the better English grasses are seldom seen to much advantage when growing within a danthonia or a browntop sward. I consider the stunted, ill-natured herbage of the better English grasses is less palatablethan the young, fresh herbage of the second rate species.

Author: YEREX
Vol / Page: 98
Edition:
Quote: On one occasion I was mustering some newly-captured deer into the race and dark shed of one of our traps and by necessity. [99] In building your trap include the wing and race leading to the dark shed, and situate the dark shed so that a vehicle can be driven up to the outside. Deer will go down a race into a dark hole of natural appearance ... we built races and sheds.

Date: 0/0/1929
Source: Flora NZ
Author: MARTIN
Vol / Page: 66
Edition: 1961 (64)
Quote: Of all the ground dwellers in the forest none equals in stature the  DAWSONIA or KING MOSS (<i>Dawsonia superba</i>), which though native also to Australia and Tasmania, nevertheless reaches its largest dimensions in the forests north of Westland, more particularly the [66] kauri forests. ... The normal height ranges from eight inches to a foot, but many specimens attain twice that height ... Truly it deserves the alternative name of GIANT MOSS.

Vol / Page: 66
Edition:
Quote: .. a foggy day meant a day off on pay (known as a day for a King).
Notes:

Date: 0/0/2000
Source: High Times in the High Country
Author: KERR
Vol / Page: 166
Edition:
Quote: We decided we'd have a day for the queen - no work, full pay - an old mustering convention. [day for a king]
Notes:

day for/on the king/queen
Homonym Number:
Word Class:phrase
Sense Number:
Definition:a day off.
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/0/1947
Source: Wayleggo
Author: NEWTON
Vol / Page: 119
Edition:
Quote: ... he and his dogs have a day off [on a foggy day] - in musterers' parlance - `a day for a king.'
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1951
Source: High Country
Author:
Vol / Page: 43
Edition:
Quote: When you wake up in the morning in a mustering hut and hear the rain beating on the roof someone is sure to poke his head out of the door and look around and say: `Its a day for the Kingboys!' I don't know how this saying originated but it means a day of enforced idleness; often very welcome after a run of fine weather.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1978
Source: Woolgatherers
Author: PRESTON
Vol / Page: 96
Edition:
Quote: The next day being wet, all [mustering] hands stayed in camp - a `Day for the King', but not for the poor cook trying to prepare their meals over an open fire in the rain.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1982
Source: Perano Whalers
Author: GRADY
Vol / Page: 140
Edition:
Quote: As well as superstitions, the whalers of Tory Channel had a few time-honoured habits. One of these was known as `a-day-for-the-Queen'. Its main application seems to have been when a whaler had had a heavy day on the grog and had butterflies in his stomach and head the nextday in the form of a hangover. If, for example, a harpoon-gunner like Trevor Norton was to have`a-day-for-the-Queen', he would be on a kind of half-alert. After a solid day on the booze he might find a nice, quiet bunk on board the Perano mother ship  Tuatea, where he could nestle down rather than being on lookout duty up on the hill.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1954
Source: Health of Fieldworkers: NZ Forest Service, The
Author: LILEY et al
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote: ... although no objection is made to `having a day on the king or queen', nearly every day is worked in the bush regardless of the weather.
Notes:

Date: 18/7/1928
Source: NZ Free Lance
Author:
Vol / Page: 35
Edition:
Quote: The introduction of the Limited train between Auckland and Wellington made an immediate appeal to the popular imagination... The introduction of a summer running train, which took advantage of the daylight, was also 'limited in its accommodation'... It brought about a desire for more specific titles, so "Daylight Limited" and "Night Limited" became the terms commonly used in referring to them.

daylight training
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/9/1943
Source: Education
Author:
Vol / Page: 2 (4): 23
Edition:
Quote: During recent years a new piece of educational jargon has become current in New Zealand - `daylight training' of apprentices. It is a phrase that is not known in England, where the words `daytime release' are used as a label to a process parallel, though not identical with, that now developing here. ... It became current in New Zealand during the hearings of the Commission of Inquiry into Apprenticeship and Related Matters, 1944, and has continued in use though the wording of the Apprentices' Act does not include it [but uses] `technical training during working hours.'
Notes: (H.C. McQueen, Commissioner of Apprenticeship)

dead bird

Sense Number:
Definition:1898 MORRIS Austral Eng. 115/2 Dead-bird, in Australia, a recent slang term,meaning `a certainty'. The metaphor is from pigeon-shooting, where the bird being let loose in front of a good shot is as good as dead.

Date: 0/0/1913
Source: NZ Geol. Survey Bulletin
Author:
Vol / Page: No.16 (NS) 98-9
Edition:
Quote: In the Aroha Subdivision, as in other mining areas of the Hauraki Peninsula, a distinction between `kindly' and `dead' country is made by miners. ... `Kindly' country for each locality is country in which lodes of that locality may carry valuable ore, while `dead' country is country in which the lodes become barren and small, or pinch out altogether.
Notes: (Henderson and Bartrum)

Date: 14/10/1872
Source: Daily Southern Cross
Author:
Vol / Page: 2
Edition:
Quote: This morning it was 12ft. from wall to wall, but of this great width some 3ft. or 4 ft. was dead country not worth crushing.

Distances are very deceptive in this sort of country. You can travel all day towards a landmark and never seem to get any closer. Then bang, you're suddenly there. Something to do with dead ground I suppose.

Quote: Karaka berries, purple, fell and rotted to nothing if the birds didn't find them. <i>Ibid.</i> 126 There was a dark trail, ... and a stream came with edgings of fine malachite ferns, ... Purple berries lay fallen, rich as damsons but not as big, and good only for the fantails ...  <i>Ibid.</i>  xx But ours [sc. leaves of history], darker, might cry, `Where is Selwyn? Where is Rutherford? Where is Katherine, with weeds on her grave at Fontainebleau, when what she really wanted was the dark berry along our creeks? (Don't you remember? We call them Dead Man's Bread.)

dead marine

Sense Number:

Date: 0/0/1953
Source: Unorganized Games
Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Vol / Page: 2/770
Edition:
Quote: It is important to distinguish these `Action-Terms' of marbles from the innumerable merely descriptive marble terms which have no effect on the course of the action - terms such asRinger, In, Smug, Dead Stick, Skun, Skinned, Sported off, Scat, Cannons, Dubs, Kills, Funs, Keeps, Pink.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1972
Source: Folkgames of Children
Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Vol / Page: 175
Edition:
Quote: Some of the typical terms used in marbles referred to the act of shooting and the movement of the marbles. Those related to ways of shooting marbles were cribbing, firsts, fudging, funks, funnicks, funnigans, flunks, forces, knee-high, knuckle-down-stiff, knuckles, and lasts. Terms connected with the movement of the marbles were: cannons, clears, dead-stick, double-hits, fires, funs, gees, haystacks, in smug, keeps, kills, kisses, lay-ups, manyes, ones, pink, ringer, rolls, scat, screws, skinned, skun, spiders, sported-off, stays, stops, tracks, throughs.

deal-fish

Sense Number:

Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/0/1881
Source: TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page: 13/196
Edition:
Quote: In shape, [the family Trachypteridae] are usually long, deep, and very much compressed and flattened on the sides, so much so that their local appellations always embody some idea of these peculiarities - such as ribband-fish, lath or deal fish, band fish or blade fish, and also oar-fish.
Notes: (Clarke)

Date: 0/0/1927
Source: Natural History of Canterbury
Author:
Vol / Page: 198
Edition:
Quote: The Oar-fish, 12 to 20 feet long, with a high, flame-tipped  head-crest (the elongated fin rays) is probably the sea-serpent of repute. Its pelvic fins are narrow, elongated processes, hence the name Oar-fish. The Deal-fish is much smaller, but of the same type, but we know very little of the habits of either of them.
Notes: 1927 Archey `Native Fishes of Canterbury' in Speight et al. Natural History of Canterbury 198

Dee
Homonym Number: 1
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:a D-shaped iron clip or loop on a saddle serving to carry suspended articles.
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/0/1866
Source: Station Life in NZ
Author: BARKER
Vol / Page: 82
Edition: 1870
Quote: We were well mounted, and all our luggage consisted of my little travelling-bag ... and what is termed a `swag' in front of F--'s saddle; that is, a long narrow bundle, in this instance enclosed in a neat waterproof case, and fastened with two straps to the `D's,' which are the steel loops let in in four places to all colonial saddles, for the purpose of carrying blankets, &c.; they derive their name apparently from their resemblance to the letter.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1898
Source: Merriam-Webster Third International
Author:
Vol / Page: 2021
Edition:
Quote: Dee (d&emacr.), n. [Written also D.] A steel loop attached to a saddle, for suspending packages; - so called from its shape, which resembles the letter D.

Vol / Page: ch ii

On to other D's, with which his saddle was amply provided, he strapped his Erewhonian boots, a tin pannikin, and a billy that would hold about a quart.

Dee
Homonym Number: 1
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:2
Definition:
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:cits; see also deeing.
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/0/1950
Source: Personal Communication
Author: R. GILBERD
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote: A `ropey' will learn to snipe - which is a highly-skilled operation. The butt end of a clean-trimmed log is trimmed of angles. V's are cut at points opposite each other at the butt end (usually) and are connected by a Dee which runs round in a D from one to the other. In the Dee is laid a `strop', a short length of cable with an eye in each end. The eyes are connected with each other and to a short chain by a shackle; and the chain is attached to `the rope' with a hitch.
Notes: R. GILBERD Okaihau

Date: 0/0/1952
Source: NZ Forest Glossary
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote: DEE: A groove in the front end of a log into which a strop is fitted for hauling.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1969
Source: From Forest to Farm
Author: MOORE
Vol / Page: 42
Edition:
Quote: [The log] was hauled by wire rope or chain bridle. This was attached sometimes by cutting a `D' in the top half of the nose of the log, or more often by two heavy spiked `dogs' which were driven in each side of the log ...

Quote: The land transfer system contrasted with the older deeds system, introduced in 1841 as a reformed version of traditional English real property law whereby rights to ownership depended on  the existence and validity of a chain of documents. The term title deeds derives from this.

deep thinker

Domain:[none]
Region:[none]

Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/0/1983
Source: Down from Marble Mountain
Author: HENDERSON
Vol / Page: 260
Edition:
Quote: Puzzled, we hear of `Deep Thinkers'. A member of the 5th Reinforcements, nearing the last of the volunteer New Zealand soldiers because `the rush to the colours' in this war was much more subdued, was heard to observe: `Yes, I must admit I did some deep thinking before joining up.' From then to the end of World War Two, the 5th Reinforcements were known as the `Deep Thinkers'.
Notes:

Deepfreeze
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: The operational name for the original1955-56 summer pre-IGY US Navy Expeditionto the Ross Sea and Antarctica,subsequently applied to later expeditionsand, with the establishment of aDeepfreeze Base in Christchurch, appliedin NZ to any US Navy or US ScienceFoundation operations or personnelassociated with the Antarctic.

deer track
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/9/1958
Source: Tararua
Author:
Vol / Page: 25
Edition:
Quote: In recent years there seems to have been a tendency to use both track and trail and to differentiate between them. A trail seems to be something narrow and perhaps rather hardto follow - a way marked only by blazes or worn by animals, usually deer. A track seems to be something broader, cut or formed by man. ... A well-known older Club member made this distinction when, on hearing him speak of a deer trail, I asked him what he thought to be the difference between track and  trail. I remarked that I thought it a very recent distinction, one not occurring in the Club until about 1957. He disagreed, believing it to be one he had always known. Yet, on looking through The Tramper,  I could not find deer trail used until 1944, but deer track occurs from the first number in 1928 onwards, and he himself had used it in 1940. It remains to be seen whether this distinction will become established. In the meantime deer track still seems to be used far more than deer trail.
Notes: Ruth Mason `Track and Trail'

Source: Dictionary of the Underworld
Author: PARTRIDGE
Vol / Page: 183
Edition: 1961
Quote: (Usually pl.) A policeman: Australian: since ca. 1880: 1889, B and L, `The demons put pincher on me', `I was apprehended'; 1891, F and H; ob. They are `the very devil' - from the criminal's point of view. Hence, a detective: New Zealand: 1932, Nelson Baylis (private letter); by 1935, also Australian; 1941 Kylie Tennant, The Battlers, `Demons' or plain-clothes detectives'; 1942, Baker; extant.

depasturage licence
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:the right, by payment of a fee, to graze stock on specified Crown land; = depasturing licence
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/0/1898
Source: Contributions to the Early History of New Zealand
Author:
Vol / Page: 59
Edition:
Quote: When the selection [of the N.Z. Company share of the Otago Block] had been made the Crowngrant was to be issued, and there was an understanding that if Colonel Wakefield desired stillmore land he was to have it. This was the origin of what was afterwards known as thedepasturage licences, under which settlers were authorised to run cattle and sheep in the adjoining districts. <i>Ibid.</i> 138-139 Under the original terms, land purchasers were entitled upon payment of an annual license fee of 10s. 6d. to depasture or run sheep and cattle upon such waste lands within the block as remained unappropriated. ... though Captain Cargill was then gazetted Commissioner of Crown Lands for the Otago block only, he received no definite instructions upon the subject of granting the runs. [139] The result was that he merely filed the applications for depasturage licenses as they were presented to him, whilst the applicants were left to pursue their further course as seemed best to them.
Notes:

On being answered in the negative, he appeared satisfied; at the same timecomplaining, that the missionaries did not treat him with due respect, but called him a `devil,' because he would not be converted.

[92] ... My book on native insects says the `darning needle' nickname derives from a tradition that the dragonflies sew up the ears of delinquents. And that a Maori legend records a chief who dispatched an army of them (he would have calledthem kapokapowai) to destroy an enemy and all his habitations.

dew nappy
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/0/1980
Source: Ghost Towns of NZ
Author: McGILL
Vol / Page: 93
Edition:
Quote: Fred has the `pensions' used for fantan, round metal discs with a square hole in the middle, and  a`dew nappy', the ivory half-ball that the game was played with. Pensions were put on the four corners of the card, or points between, and two people took the bank. Even money was paid on the corners and three to one in the middle. There would be several hundred pounds sometimes waiting on the half-roll of the dew nappy.
Notes: Check with DMcG whether he means to refer to fantan or to a game dew nappy.

Edition:
Quote: Generally there has been little change in fellmongering practice since 1892. Skins are still cold-water washed in `dollies' or paddles, deburring machines are no longer used, but the de-wooling paint is applied on a moving conveyor instead of on the piled skins.

Date: 0/0/1978

Author: MOORE & IRWIN
Vol / Page: 182
Edition:
Quote: DIANELLA NIGRA. Turutu, blueberry, inkberry, or whistles thrives in lowland scrub, on clay banks, and along bush tracks. ... The reddish leaf-base leaves a yellow scar when broken ...; often it is folded into a tube so that skilful blowing can force air out in an ear-splitting whistle. Shining berries, ranging from palest grey to almost purple, or clean blue and white like old china, ripen in great numbers but they drop at a touch; ...

The Irish use may be recent too, perhaps as a result of Mary O'Regan(?) president of Ireland who made a major speech  (about 1990 I think) in which she said that Ireland should reach out to its emigrants. Coming out of the KWC, there has been formed KEA (Kiwi Expatriates Association) to harness our diaspora for New Zealand's benefit.

dicken
Homonym Number:
Word Class:exclamation
Sense Number:
Definition:constr. (aw) dicken! or dicken on that!; an exclamation or interjection of disbelief, disgust, etc., never commonly used in NZ and now (1984) obs in many localities even in children's usage.
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/0/1937
Source: Vintage Murder
Author: MARSH
Vol / Page: 238
Edition:
Quote:  `Aw dikkon, Mr A!' said Wade. `What did you say?' `Haven't you heard that one, sir? I suppose it's New Zealand digger slang. `Dikkon'. It's the same as if you'd say `Come off it'. Used to hear it on the Peninsula. `Aw dikkon, dig'' [check cit and edn]

Notes: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng.Dict.]

Date: 0/0/1988
Source: Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A
Author: McGILL
Vol / Page: 36
Edition:
Quote: dicken disgust or disbelief or surprised belief, in form of an interjection, largely replaced by `really!' or `really?'; an antipodean contraction of `the dickens' or `what the dickens!', being a euphemism for the devil. - dicken on that! go easy, will you!; eg `You want me to help you lift that dirty big post? Dicken on that, mate.'
Notes:

Author:

Dieffenbach's rail
Homonym Number: 1
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: (?obs)
Citations
Date: 0/0/1988
Source: Birds of New Zealand
Author: BULLER
Vol / Page: 121
Edition:
Quote: `Dieffenbach's Rail. . . . This beautiful Rail was brought from the Chatham Islands by Dr. Dieffenbach in 1842, and named by Mr. Gray in compliment to this enterprising naturalist. The adult specimen in the British Museum, from which my description was taken, is unique, and seems likely to remain so.'
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1840
Source: Journal of Royal Geog. Society
Author: DIEFFENBACH
Vol / Page: 11/195-215
Edition:
Quote: The forest is enlivened by numerous tuis or mocking-birds; a little green parroquet flocks in hundreds to the potato-fields ... The mako-mako, the finest songster in New Zealand, is also found here, being another species of the honey-eater. The large New Zealand pigeon, called `kukupa', finds plentiful food here ... A new kind of rail was formerly very common; ...
Notes: 1840 Dieffenbach An Account of the Chatham Islands Journal of the Royal Geographical Society 11 pp195-215 in 1984 Holmes Chatham Islands 95

Date: 0/0/1873
Source: Birds of New Zealand
Author: BULLER
Vol / Page: 179
Edition: 1888 2nd edn 2/123
Quote: RALLUS DIEFFENBACHII. (DIEFFENBACH'S RAIL.) ... <i>Native name</i>. Moeriki. ... [180] This beautiful Rail was brought from the Chatham Islands by Dr. Dieffenbach in 1842 ... [1888 edn, 2/12, places this  specimen in Hutton's <i>Cabalus modestus</i> as Hutton's Rail.]
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1966
Source: Birds of New Zealand
Author: FALLA et al.
Vol / Page: 105
Edition:
Quote: <i>Note</i>: Dieffenbach's Rail (<i>Rallus dieffenbachi</i>), once abundant in the Chathams Islands, was similar to the Banded Rail in so many respects that that it may be regarded as a strong sub-species of <i>philippensis</i>. The last specimen was obtained in 1840.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1970
Source: Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ
Author:
Vol / Page: 41
Edition: 1980
Quote: 131.b. <i>Rallus philippensis dieffenbachii</i> Gray, 1843 <i>Dieffenbach's Rail</i> Chatham Island, extinct (one specimen, 1840).

Vol / Page: No. 308/2
Edition:

We, the N.Z.R.B., prefer to be addressed as "diggers" rather than "dinks" which was the original mode of address.

Author:
Vol / Page: 6
Edition:
Quote: "Digger" is now the common form of salutation between privates. It applied to the Maoris only at one time. They do a lot of pioneer work, such as digging trenches, but as we all do more or less navvy work, the term is universally used among the New Zealanders. Really the meaning is "Friend" now.
Notes: This is from a letter from an Auckland soldier;

Vol / Page: 23
Edition: 1978
Quote: It is called by some digger-mania, by others digger-phobia. This dire disease is usually developed about a month after the victim has commenced digging; its symptoms are very varied and curious, and are anything but agreeable to those who are unfortunately connected with the poor afflicted one.

dill
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:stupid person; fool; dupe (occas.), awkward, clumsy person.
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/0/1949
Source: Dictionary of the Underworld
Author: PARTRIDGE
Vol / Page: 186
Edition:
Quote: A dupe; an easy victim: Australian, esp. confidence tricksters': since the 1920s. In, e.g. Baker, 1942. Perhaps silly billy>Billy>Billy?)> Bill> by `rhyme', dill; but prob. ex daffydill, illiterate for daffodil ... (cf pill @n with similar, though harsher, connotation) perhaps dialectal relation to dull (OE dyle), or perhaps a NZ shortening from dilly (aj) (though the reverse may be true, dilly (aj)  from dill @n; dill is a more friendly term than dool (aj doolish) which is applied in anger or disgust with somebody's stupidity.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1953
Source: Unorganized Games
Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Vol / Page: 2/677
Edition:
Quote: Some of the [slang] expressions listed by children in two schools are: `Up the shoot, going eyes out, bullswool, go jump in the lake, ... shivery dick, shiver me timbers, ... you're telling I, got iton the brain, like smoke in a wheelbarrow' (Kaitaia), `Sheila, crow, bud, frig it, grub, holy moses, blast it, mole, balls to you, shut your face, ... nerts to you, go bite your back, have a roll, fluff off, scram, ants in your pants, rag bag, ... you're bats, dronk, drongo, dill, dip, dippy, ya big lug, greetings gruesome, who dented your beak. (South Wellington).

Date: 14/10/1933
Source: Press, The
Author:
Vol / Page: 15
Edition:
Quote: Dingbats. - Slang, of Australian origin, for delirium tremens. The dingbats, I believe, are really the snakes, weasels, etc., which a sufferer sees. ([1890-1910], but since when I am not sure.)
Notes: (Acland Gloss.)

Date: 0/0/1937
Source: Dictionary of Slang
Author: PARTRIDGE
Vol / Page: 221
Edition:

Date: 0/0/1919

Author:
Vol / Page: 20

Notes:

Date: 0/0/1968
Source: Growing Better Wool
Author: HENDERSON
Vol / Page: 81
Edition:
Quote: Dingy wool - in practice this kind of wool is described with a variety of names. In New Zealand the most common names are 'dingy' .. There [in Australia] the term 'dingy' is most often used to describe discolored wool in general. The following discussion is confined to wool bearing excessive amounts of sand, earth and dust and for simplicity it is called dingy wool. It is the rule rather than the exception to find very weak back wool in dingy fleeces.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1963
Source: Gallipoli to the Somme
Author: AITKEN
Vol / Page: 46
Edition:
Quote: Next came the New Zealand Rifle Brigade from Mersa Matruh, first the 2nd Battalion, nicknamed the `Square Dinks' (a `square dinkum bloke' being idiomatic Australian for a genuine fellow) from the distinctive black patch on the upper sleeve; later the `Diamond Dinks', who wore a diamond patch and had been in action with British and Sikhs in the defeat of the Senussi on Christmas Day. The alternative name of the Rifle Brigade, the E.L.O. (the Earl of Liverpool's Own) had been quietly allowed to lapse.
Notes:

Author: McGILL

Dink
Homonym Number: 1
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:the Dinkums
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:	(WW1)
Citations
Date: 11/3/1916
Source: Letter
Author: ANON
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote: I have seen a number of university men of the Rifle Brigade, generally known to us as the Dinks - a name they have cheerfully accepted and try to live up to.  [fn] The newspapers urging enlistment in 1915 declared that the later men, joining the forces with motives of reasoned patriotism, would be more praiseworthy than the `impetuous spirits' of the Main Body. Hence thesardonic nickname of `the Dinks' - dinkum soldiers - attached to the new brigade.
Notes: 1916 March 11 Letter from Egypt in 1965 Malthus ANZAC 156

Quote: Colloquially the Rifle Brigade Battalions were known as `Dinks', a term applied to them on their arrival in Egypt, 1916, and alluding to the special patronage which they enjoyed of the Governor-General of the Dominion, and to their peculiarities of drill and dress.

Source: Evening Post
Author:
Vol / Page: 12
Edition:
Quote: The New Zealand Rifle Brigade, perhaps better known as the `Dinks', will hold a reunion in Wellington ... (How did they get their name? The black buttons, badges, and blazes, and theunusual drill of the New Zealand Rifle Brigade led to their being dubbed `the dinkum soldiers.' Shortened to `The Dinks' it was accepted as an honourable title.)

Notes: When my eye first  fleetingly caught this par, I thought it referred to NZers. This actually states that it refers to Australians but the similarity of names is such that I wonder if this is a sub-editor's misinterpretation of the review or his precis of another paragraph.

Author:
Vol / Page: 4
Edition:
Quote: A reviewer of Captain Bean's book "Letters from France," quotes the nicknames of the successive drafts of Australian forces to fight for the cause of the Old Country. "The Tourists" came first, - people out to see what the adventure was like. The next shipment were the "Dinkums", the true men; followed by the "Super-Dinkums". Then arrived the "War Babies" and the "Chocolate Soldiers", and after them the "Hard Thinkers" who thought very hard before they came, and last of all the "Neutrals".

Date: 3/12/2004
Source: Dominion Post  Sport & RaceForm
Author:
Vol / Page: 8
Edition:
Quote: "...that was the first time I was a Dirty Dirty for a team, but I think I'm a better person for it... It's made me think back to the guys who were the Dirty Dirties in those teams and the jobs they did." Being  Dirty Dirty is a thankless job. During the week the unwanted players are used as cannon fodder for the team, running in defence at training and trying to simulate a game atmosphere without (of course) injuring the guys playing in their place. Closer to the match they have to disappear, to give the playing 22 a bit of space, then on game day they are used for everything from ferrying bags to picking up the dirty playing gear after the game.

Definition:a judicial tribunal designed to determine small civil claims cheaply and informally.

Domain:[none]
Region:[none]

Pronunciation:
Notes: Jim Cameron writes: Known as a <i>small claims tribunal</i> 1976-1988. Presided over by <i>referees</i>. Disputes Tribunals Act 1988.

Edition:
Quote: Some obsolete  terms  (e.g.  entail, foreclosure, probation)  are not noted as historical only.    Even the Dictionary of New Zealand English (DNZE) (1997) is patchy in its coverage of legal terms, having for example no entry for disputes tribunal, family protection, incorporated society, Maori option, protection order, resource consent.

District Court
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/1/1999
Source: NZWords
Author:
Vol / Page: 1
Edition:
Quote: Magistrates courts were renamed district courts and their presiding judges district court judges in 1981, but the term magistrate in New Zealand denoted stipendiary magistrates rather than justices of the peace, who were and are usually referred to simply as justices or JPs. (District court has itself a history.  Originally district courts were intermediate courts created in 1858; they were squeezed out between the Supreme Court (now the High Court) and the magistrates courts and were formally abolished in 1925.) The latest episode of this serial is the creation in 1998 of community magistrates to sit in district courts and exercise minor criminal jurisdiction.
Notes:

diversion
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:n. in criminal procedure, a system for giving a chance for a first- time criminal defendant in lesser crimes to perform community service, make restitution for damage due to the crime, obtain treatment for alcohol or drug problems and/or counselling for antisocial or mentally unstable conduct. If the defendant cooperates and the diversion results in progress, the charges eventually may be dismissed. Usually diversion may not be granted for a second offense.
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 15/3/2004
Source: Salient
Author:
Vol / Page: No. 3/33
Edition:
Quote: Diversion is a system by which first-time offenders can be charged with a minor offence and escape without a conviction.

do a skate
Homonym Number:

Sense Number:
Definition:to hurry off; to decamp (cf. scale v.)
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/0/1988
Source: Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A
Author: McGILL
Vol / Page: 103
Edition:
Quote: <i>skate </i> phr. do a skate <i> to disappear hurriedly; aka</i> skate off; <i>eg `Potts figured there was trouble brewing and did a skate.' c. 1925.</i> - phr. <i>go for a skate</i> a fall, mistake, failure, blunder or dismissal; eg `If he doesn't shape up soon he'll go for a skate.' -<i> skate over/around</i> to avoid, move over or blur something disconcerting; eg `She's always skating around the question, never really answering directly.' NZA.

do the block
Homonym Number:
Word Class:phrase
Sense Number:
Definition:to promenade or parade the streets
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/0/1898
Source: Austral English
Author: MORRIS
Vol / Page: 36
Edition:
Quote: <i>Block, doing the</i> v. lounging in the fashionable promenade. In Melbourne, it is Collins Street, between Elizabeth and Swanston Streets. In Sydney, `The Block' is that portion of the city bounded by King, George, Hunter, and Pitt Streets. It is now really two blocks, but was all in one till the Government purchased the land for the present Post Office, and then opened a new street from George to Pitt Street. Since then the Government, having purchased more land, has made the street much wider, and it is now called Martin's Place. <i>Ibid.</i> 37 <i>Block, on the (1) On the promenade above referred to. </i>
Notes:

Author: O'REGAN
Vol / Page: 15

Quote: The gilded loafer `does the block' and elevates his snout/ To see the rough-dressed fossicker, white haired and broken down/ Who strays from out the lonely wilds for his Christmas booze in town.

do the Pacific Slope
Homonym Number:
Word Class:phrase
Sense Number:
Definition:(of a wanted criminal) to flee the country
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/0/1902
Source: Zealandia's Guerdon
Author: WALKER
Vol / Page: 292
Edition:
Quote: Perhaps he [sc a missing man] accomplished the `Pacific Slope'. <i>Ibid.</I> 326 He [sc.the detective] has packed so many `confidence men' off to penitentiary ... that the others have done the `Pacific Slope' in various directions, chiefly towards Australia.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1938
Source: Early Days of Canterbury
Author: GILKISON
Vol / Page: 133
Edition:
Quote: In the 'seventies and 'eighties many fraudulent debtors, embezzlers and rich thieves escaped from New Zealand before arrest, by doing what came to be known as the `Pacific Slope'. Someone discovered that the Sandwich Islands, which were then ruled by a native queen, had no extradition treaty with New Zealand and consequently rogues who were much `wanted' by the police in this country on reaching Honolulu could laugh at writs and law proceedings.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1934
Source: Spur of Morning
Author: MULGAN
Vol / Page: 42
Edition:
Quote: `Poor old Tom! He's never been the same since his partner did the Pacific slope.'
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1956
Source: Levins
Author: GORE
Vol / Page: 186
Edition:
Quote: He never returned. Tetley had done what in those days was termed `The Pacific Slope', and was last heard of in South America, that haven for absconders and those anxious to shelve their responsibilities.
Notes:

Date: 4/6/1902
Source: Tuapeka Times
Author:
Vol / Page: 3
Edition:
Quote: The employes [sic] at a certain flaxmill in the district (says the "Manawatu Times") awoke one morning to find that their overseer had "done the Pacific slope" with nearly GBP200 of their wages in his pocket.
Notes: Reprinted from the Manawatu Times

Date: 19/11/1889
Source: North Otago Times
Author:
Vol / Page: 4
Edition:
Quote: The Wanganui Chronicle says: The latest idea in "sweeps" is what is known as the "Pacific Slope" stakes. All the names of the prominent business men are entered, and the drawer of the next person who leaves his Wanganui creditors and crosses the Pacific, scoops the pool. We hear that the stakes are large, so it may be worth the while of the holder of them to do the "slope" himself.
Notes:

Quote: In the simplest form of Tip Cat the players competed to see who could hit the cat farthest. The cat was a thin, six-inch stick with pointed ends. Their bat (or dog) was a round stick about the size of a cricket wicket (two and a half feet long). The cat was placed on the ground, tapped on its point, and then as it jumped up into the air, hit once more.

Dog Town
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:an early nickname for Port Chalmers (cf. the occasional PIGTOWN for Picton)
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: (coastal seamen's)
Citations
Date: 0/0/1948
Source: Port Chalmers
Author: BOWMAN
Vol / Page: 53
Edition:
Quote: During the [1890] strike about 100 seamen unattached in Port Chalmers stayed in hotels and boarding houses, but a large number of them found residence in the "baches" in what was called "Sweat Rag Alley", consisting of a number of small baches or cribs in a double row where the Corporation Yard now is. Each bach housed three or four men and it was said that each man had a dog. From this fact, the area became known as "Dogtown".
Notes:

Date: 8/7/1911
Source: NZ Truth
Author:
Vol / Page: 315/7/1
Edition:
Quote: To the uninitiated this may mean nothing, but, to those in the know, the quickest way to cause a riot and to raise an insurrection is to call an inhabitant of Port Chalmers a dweller in Dogtown.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/2001
Source: Curious Questions
Author: CRYER
Vol / Page: 63
Edition:
Quote: There are two explanations for the term Dog Town. The first has its clue in the name of the town, Port Chalmers, which obviously had a lot of docks. As with the Isle of Dogs in London, there is a belief that in the old days the docks of Port Chalmers caused it to be referred to as Dock Town, and the word became corrupted. But there are also legends that.. there were always many seamen about, sometimes unemployed, and all of them were accompanied by their dogs. Most of these men lived in cottages in George Street which became known locally as Dog Town and the name spread to mean Port Chalmers in general. It's occasionally heard even today.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1973
Source: Days of Fortune
Author: STEWART
Vol / Page: 42
Edition:
Quote: And during the troubles [sc. an 1890 strike] , about 100 seamen from other ports stayed in baches in an area called 'Sweat Rag Alley' in Port Chalmers. I t was said that each resident there had a dog - and the name 'Dogtown' unfortunately stuck to the Borough for a long time.
Notes:

dogfish
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:.
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:northern spiny dogfish
Pronunciation:
Notes: [not NZ specific]  a small shark of the .... fam.; also called gummy shark, manga, occas. mango, rig; valuable food source of the early Maori, and of the modern New Zealander as freq.  the 'fish' of 'fish and chips'; any of various small sharks of the smoothhound fam. Triakidae esp. <i>Mustelus lenticulatus</i> (gummy [shark], rig, spotted shark, pioke, spotted or smooth dogfish) and <i>Galeorhinus galeus</i> (tope, grey or school shark) or [spiny] dogfish fam. Squalidae esp.  <i>Squalus acanthias</i> ([spotted] spiny dogfish, spotted dog, southern dogfish, koinga); other species include the grey spiny or northern dogfish, <i>Squalus blainevillei</i>, and Plunket's shark, <i>Scymnodon plunketii</i>. See also koinga, manga, occas. mango, okeoke. [Transf. use of Northern Hemisphere name.]

Date: 0/0/1967
Source: Animals of NZ, The
Author: NATUSCH
Vol / Page: 199
Edition:
Quote: Family SQUALIDAE Includes two species of <i>Squalus </i>, the brown  (<i> S. blainvillei </i>) and spotted (<i> S. acanthias </i>) dogfishes; one  species of <i> Scymnodon (S. plunketi </i>), which grows up to 5 ft long and is also known as the brown dogfish; one species of <i> Centrophorus (C. squamosus)</i>; one species of <i> Centrophorus (C. squamosus)</i>; one species of the long-snouted <i> Deania (D. calcea)</i>; one of <i> Scymnodalatias </i>, a genus in which the spine is missing; two luminescent sharks of the genus <i> Etmopterus </i>; and two of <i> Centroscymnus </i>. Of these squalid sharks, <i> Squalus </i> is the most commonly caught.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1924
Source: NZ Journal of Science & Technology
Author:
Vol / Page: 6/263
Edition:
Quote: <I>Mustelus antarcticus</I>. Synonyms: <I>Galeus antarcticus</I> and <I>Galeorhinus antarcticus</I>. The smooth-hound, or gummy (<I>Mustelus antarcticus</I>) ... is one of the small sharks commonly taken by trawlers around new Zealand, and popularly termed `dogfish.' The family is distinguished by the blunt pavement-like teeth - hence the popular name `gummy,' in use in Australia, where the species is also common.
Notes:  (Phillipps)

Date: 0/0/1936
Source: Handbook for New Zealand, The

Notes: (Phillipps)

A secondary feature of some doggy wools is a very lustrous appearance. So far doggy wool has attracted notice only in Merino wool and wool from breeds with Merino in their ancestry.

doghook
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:Dog-hook is also occas. used (e.g. by watersiders) for bale-hook, a small steel hook with, usually, a wooden handle at right angles to the curve of the hook (see Web3), and this is its sense in b. below.] a. (bushmen's) use) An iron bar with a bent prong [i.e. a `dog' or iron claw] for securing or  hoisting a log, etc; see also [?what] [?canthook, ?chain jack].

dog-leg
Homonym Number:
Word Class:adjective
Sense Number:
Definition:In full dogleg(ged) fence; applied to a primitive kind of fence made of rough timber or poles, crossed spars, which are the doglegs, placed at intervals, keep in place a low rail resting on short posts, and are themselves fixed by heavy saplings resting in the forks above (Morris); but see cits.
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/0/1898
Source: Merriam-Webster Third International
Author:
Vol / Page: 2021
Edition:
Quote: Dog'.leg fence'. (d&omacr.g'.l&ebreve.g f&ebreve.ns'.).} A kind of rough fence, Dog'.leg (d&omacr.g'.l&ebreve.g), n. } made of posts and rails. Light posts (about 3 ft. 6 in. in height) are arranged in pairs, crosswise, so as to form a fork about 18 in. from the top. Each fork supports a rail, which is laid slantwise and plaited in and out among the three or four neighbouring supports, its lower end being driven into the ground. Sometimes the whole is capped with a horizontal rail, laid from fork to fork.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1935
Source: Gael Fares Forth, The
Author: McKENZIE
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote: The `dog-legged' type of fence ... was apparently a purely Canadian type ... made of stakes of varying length and the trunks of small trees.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1943
Source: Memoirs of Pioneers
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote: There was no fencing wire in those days [in Auckland ca1865] so we had to make what is called a `dog-leg fence'. This was composed of stakes driven crossways in the ground and the long sticks laid with one end on the ground and the other end on the crossed stakes.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1955
Source: Land of My Children
Author: WILSON
Vol / Page: 66
Edition:
Quote: The tiny flower patch surrounding the shack was protected by a dog-leg fence - that is a fence of crooked sticks and branches held together by their own crookedness.
Notes:

Date: 0/10/1965
Source: NZ Geographer
Author:
Vol / Page: 147
Edition:
Quote: The dog-leg fence, found in North America only in the Maritime Provinces of Canada, reappeared in the Nova Scotian settlement at Waipu, and from there spread to some other bush settlements in the north. It was constructed by driving two crossing stakes into the ground, and in the notch of these placing a third rail which followed the direction of the fence ... It was claimed that it would keep out cattle, but the fence was never widely adopted probably because of its tendency to get out of repair easily.
Notes:  (Hargreaves `Farm Fences')

Date: 0/0/1955
Source: Dim Horizons
Author: BOSWELL
Vol / Page: 45
Edition: 1956

Date: 27/11/1769
Source: Cook's Journals
Author:
Vol / Page: 1/213
Edition: 1955
Quote: ... in each of the Canoes were two or three Cheifs [sic] and the habits of these were superior to any we had yet seen, the Cloth they were made on was of the best sort and cover'd on the out side with Dog skins put on in such a manner as to look agreeable to the Eye. Few of these people were tattow'd or mark'd in the face like those we have seen farther to the south, but several had their Backsides tattou'd much in the same manner as the Inhabitants of the Islands within the Tropics.

dog-whistle/dog-whistle politics
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:(politics) a concealed, coded, or unstated idea, usually divisive or politically dangerous, nevertheless understood by the intended hearers.
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]

Pronunciation:

The whole idea of a "mainstream New Zealander" is bogus anyway .. except as dogwhistle code for "real New Zealander". Which is why Jordan's annoyed. And so am I.
Notes: Just Left: Jordon Carter 27/6/2005 http://jtc.blogs.com/just_left/2005.06/gays_aren't_main.html

Just as a dog-whistle is inaudible to humans but is heard by every canine within miles, Howard has been beaming messages at targeted groups-anti-abortion campaigners, and people hostile to immigrants, gypsies and asylum-seekers-which, if broadcast in the normal way, might repel the majority of voters.

dollar
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:2

Author: TURNER
Vol / Page: 133
Edition:
Quote: The present colloquial ... use of dollar, usually in half a dollar, `half a crown' in New Zealand, but in Australia, where half-crowns are not in use, two shillings, should help the natural adoption of the new official term
Notes:

Date: 0/10/1977
Source: NZ Numismatic Journal
Author:
Vol / Page: 15
Edition:
Quote: The crown was called a bull, a cartwheel, a caser, five  bob, and most familiar of all a dollar, the latter dating from the time when the rate of exchange was four US dollars to the pound. The only instance recorded of Cockney rhyming slang term for a coin is Oxford scholar, the derivation from dollar being obvious. The half crown was called a half-dollar, a half-bull, half-caser, two-and-a-kick, and  two-and-a-buck. In the latter instance buck stands for sixpence, though apparently this term was rarely used by itself for that coin denomination, but almost always in association with a number of shillings. The florin seems to have had fewer English nicknames, only  two bob being recorded as being in use in New Zealand.
Notes:

dolly

Vol / Page:  4/158
Edition:
Quote: The pelts are first washed in pits or `dollies', with paddles revolving, in order to thoroughly remove as much as possible of adhering detritus.

Date: 0/0/1957

Author: MACDONALD
Vol / Page: 69
Edition:
Quote: Generally there has been little change in fellmongering practice since 1892. Skins are still cold-water washed in `dollies' or paddles, deburring machines are no longer used, but the de-wooling paint is applied on a moving conveyor instead of on the piled skins.

Sense Number:

Source: Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A
Author: McGILL
Vol / Page: 38
Edition:
Quote: dommyknocker a stick to beat other kids with, aka bommyknocker; origins unknown, though a `dommie' was a nickname for a Norton `Dominator' motorbike and thus for any motorcyclist, while `bommie' is a bombora or submerged reef beyond beach breakers, of interest only to Australian surfers, and their guests.

Date: 28/4/1981
Source: Personal Communication
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote: May I suggest the inclusion of the word `Donko' in any subsequent edition of your New Zealand  Dictionary. The word, which appears to mean `the lunch room or similar facilities for workers in a factory'. The word appears to have fairly wide usage in New Zealand and I have spoken to several Australians and found them unaware of it. It do not know the origin of the term and would be grateful if any of your etymologists can enlighten me.
Notes: A.R.Stone letter to editor HNZD

Date: 21/8/1982
Source: Listener (New Zealand Listener)
Author:
Vol / Page: 49
Edition:
Quote: Can you tell me the origin of the word `donko'?  My correspondent assures me it is a New Zealand term for `the tea room of a factory or work-place'. The report comes from Wanganui. ... Is it a place where you donk or dunk biscuits in your tea?
Notes: [I.A. Gordon]

doodlum-buck
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:a children's game, toodle-em-buck q.v.
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 14/4/1921
Source: Ashburton Guardian
Author:
Vol / Page: 5
Edition:
Quote: There were fancy stalls, produce tents, butchers' shops, skittle alleys, a shooting gallery, the good old game of "Doodlum Buck," bowling alleys, prize quoit boards, etc.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1953
Source: Unorganized Games
Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Vol / Page: 2/471
Edition:
Quote: Pitching games were Pitch and Toss, Quoits, Ninepins, Egg Cap and Toodle-em-buck. In the game of Toodle-em-buck (Richmond ([19]19) a piece of broom a foot in length with a button on top of it stood upright in a circle of about two fet in diameter. Players pitched another piece of broom at this upright stick from a set distance in an endeavour to knock it over and send the button out of the circle. The game was played to the cry of `Roll up, Tumble up, come and play the game of Toodle-em-Buck'. There is still occasional mention of Egg Cap (Horoeka, Alexandra).
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1972
Source: Folkgames of Children
Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Vol / Page: 167
Edition:
Quote: Another universal stone-throwing game was Ducks and Drakes (K-8), or Skipping Stones, which consisted simply in `skipping' flat stones across the water. feet in diameter and a button was placed on top of the stick. Players pitched another piece of broomstick of the same size at the upstanding piece in an attempt to knock it over and send the button outside the circle. The game was played to the cry of `Roll up, tumble up, come and play the game of Toodlle-em-buck.' <i>Ibid.</i> 172 An odd pitching game was Toodle-em-Buck (K-28) (Richmond, Nelson, 1919), in which a piece of broomstick a foot in length was placed upright in a circle about two
Notes:

Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Vol / Page: 231
Edition:
Quote: There are games recorded in this period for which there is no record before 1900 though they may well have existed under other names. .. <i>Canterbury:</i> Poor Old Tom, Rats and Rabbits and Rips,Steps, Skin the Snake, Steal a Peg, Toodle-em-Buck, The Gag;...

dopey
Homonym Number:
Word Class:adjective
Sense Number: 1
Definition:[of a ewe suffering from sleepy sickness, twin-lamb disease or preganancy toxaemia] lethargic.
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:Rural
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/0/1981
Source: Loughnan Glossary
Author: LOUGHNAN
Vol / Page: 26
Edition:
Quote: dopey or dozey: a ewe which loses interest in life is said to go dopey. Usually she has been suffering the lack of a steadily rising nutritional plane during her pregnancy and often is carrying twins. Her disease is thus sometimes termed twin-lamb disease. More correctly it is pregnancy toxaemia. [dozey]
Notes:

dopiness
Homonym Number:

Sense Number:
Definition:a deficiency disease; a form of bush sickness.
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:

Notes: (Aston) [Te Kuiti district]

Date: 0/11/1932
Source: Discovery
Author:
Vol / Page: 357/2
Edition:
Quote: Recent investigations ion New Zealand testify to ... the value of top dressing of pastyures with lime and superphosphate where sheep are affected with dopiness diseases.
Notes:  [OED2]

Date: 0/0/1936
Source: Agricultural Organization in NZ
Author:
Vol / Page: 81
Edition:
Quote: The known deficiency diseases in New Zealand apparently mainly due to the lack of some element in the food of farm animals are:- `Bush Sickness' or [mistakenly] Iron deficiency. `Dopiness' or Calcium deficiency. `Waihi Disease' or Phosphate deficiency. `Goitre' or Iodine deficiency...  Bush sickness is always found in the volcanic district on coarse rhyolitic pumice soils and `dopiness' on soils derived from fine volcanic dust or mud showers. A soil on which `dopiness' develops is a leached loam and is found on deteriorated lands, i.e., lands which originally were highly fertile due to the ashes from the `bush burn,' the land subsequently becoming gradually less productive ...
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1943
Source: NZ Journal of Science & Technology
Author:
Vol / Page: 23/323A
Edition:
Quote: It is at lambing-time that the effect of grass-grub ravages is most severe. Ewes are low in condition and have missed the `green bite from the pastures ... The normal green-feed area ... is inadequate. The result is a high mortality in young lambs, an increased susceptibility of the ewe to `dopiness,' ...
Notes:

Date: 0/7/1950
Source: NZ Journal of Agriculture
Author:
Vol / Page: 33/3
Edition:
Quote: Some green, succulent feed just before and at lambing assists in the prevention of diseases associated with lambing - dopiness (twin lamb disease or ante-partum paralysis) and milk fever.

Vol / Page: 181

Quote: New Zealand boasts four endemic waders not found elsewhere in the world. These are the black stilt, now limited to a few pairs nesting on high ground in the centre of the South Island; the shore plover, confined entirely to a small island off the Chathams, where its numbers are fairly strong; and the New Zealand dotterel, red-breasted in summer, rather curiously nesting in two discrete groups, one in the Hauraki Gulf, the other far away at and around Stewart Island -

Author: LOUGHNAN
Vol / Page: 26
Edition:
Quote: double-gate: referring to a drafting race having two gates so that the sheep can be run into any one of three check-pens. Very occasionally one may find a triple-gate race; and many saleyards boast, halfway along the race, a second pair of gates for another man.

Region:[none]
See:

Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/0/1972
Source: Folkgames of Children
Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Vol / Page: 175
Edition:
Quote: Some of the typical terms used in marbles referred to the act of shooting and the movement of the marbles. Those related to ways of shooting marbles were cribbing, firsts, fudging, funks, funnicks, funnigans, flunks, forces, knee-high, knuckle-down-stiff, knuckles, and lasts. Terms connected with the movement of the marbles were: cannons, clears, dead-stick, double-hits, fires, funs, gees, haystacks, in smug, keeps, kills, kisses, lay-ups, manyes, ones, pink, ringer, rolls, scat, screws, skinned, skun, spiders, sported-off, stays, stops, tracks, throughs.

Date: 24/1/1996
Source: Capital Times
Author:
Vol / Page: 6
Edition:
Quote: The title Doughboy comes from thetraditional Maori boiler, a pot of puha,pork bones, potatoes and a lump of wetdough, broken into little round balls,thrown in. These little dumplings arecalled doughboys (Mutumutu), and by somecruel of happy fate, depending on how youlook at it, this has become one Maorislang name for gays.
Notes:

Quote: Doughboys are dumpling-like globules of flour and baking powder, milk and water, dropped into stews and cooked. Neither damper nor doughboys feature greatly on modern menus.
Notes:

Date: 21/6/2003
Source: Dominion Post
Author:
Vol / Page: F6
Edition:
Quote: Like many Maori, the Tamiheres called these flour and suet dumplings "doughboys". Another Irish culinary inheritance, the doughboys were used to supplement the meat and vegetables and make the food go further.

dover
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:a knife; (pl.) eating tools; often in the run of the dover(s) `as much food as one can eat' `all necessary food'; cf musterers the run of the dover; ? connected with Dover stove in high country tramping or mustering huts;  ? =necessary food.  -->cf Pascoe Land Uplifted High 100 -
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 14/10/1933
Source: Press, The
Author:
Vol / Page: 15
Edition:
Quote: Dover: [1898 Morris Austral-English] gives the meaning as a clasp knife. George McMillan, who came out in 1858, told me that when he arrived it was the custom for hands to find theirown knife, fork, spoon, plate, and pannikin, which were all called dovers. A man would offer work for `a pound a week and the run of my dovers'. The expression died out in Canterbury before 1860.
Notes: (Acland Gloss.)

Date: 0/0/1947
Source: Early Runholding in Otago
Author: BEATTIE
Vol / Page: 10
Edition:
Quote: Once, in lamenting inevitable changes, a runholder exclaimed, `I wish I were back in a maimai with a plate of bark and a dover!' The saying then [ca1870] in engaging a hand was `so much a week and the run of the dover.' The dover was a Dover knife, and the `run of the dover' was as as much food as one could eat.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1989
Source: Pioneer Recollections
Author:
Vol / Page: 1/93
Edition:
Quote: He said `I tell you what, Johnson, these big houses are a curse instead of a blessing. I wish I was back in a `maimai' with a plate of bark and a dover!' The saying then in regard to wages was `So much the week and the run of the dover.' (The `dover' was a DoverKnife and the `run of the dover' was as much food as you liked to eat)
Notes: -->19?? Beattie Pioneer Recollections 1/93 (Griffiths Collection)

Date: 0/0/1984
Source: Knapdale Run, The
Author: KERSE
Vol / Page: 18
Edition:
Quote:  This `big house' [built of slabs in 1860] ... was very draughty and McNab at a time when he was suffering from a bronchial ailment, was heard to remark ..., `I tell you what, Johnson, these big houses are a curse. I wish I were back in the maimai with a plate of bark and a run of the dover'.
Notes: [a1890 in] 1984 Knapdale Run 18  [Alexander McNab: had Australian experience]

Down Under
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:Australia and New Zealand; now used of NZ (with Australia) by other than New Zealanders though pre-WW1 usage suggests a local acceptance.
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: also adjective
Citations

Author:
Vol / Page: 4 : 1

Date: 0/0/1934
Source: Children of the Poor
Author: LEE
Vol / Page: 10
Edition: 1949
Quote: In those days Antipodes meant more than `down under.' The term imaginatively suggested the edge of the world.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1945
Source: If You'd Care to Know
Author: SIMPSON
Vol / Page: 7
Edition:
Quote: [A US writer] The little Dominion of New Zealand is the more or less happy land popularly known as `Down Under.' ... It is doubtful whether the origin of the term `Down Under' will ever be known. It first came into general use during the World War of 1914-18, when the New Zealanders who fought in the ill-starred Gallipoli campaign were referred to as `the men from Down Under', but that was not the start of it. This faraway land, it seems, was known as `Down Under' in some parts of England and Scotland before the birth of the present century. The first World War merely [put] the expression into wider usage. An Auckland artist, Mr Trevor Lloyd,made it the subject of one of his cartoons at the very beginning of that great upheaval, and at least one English war correspondent used the term when writing on Gallipoli. After the year 1918 the expression fell into disuse, but during the second World War it again became popular, and I think we must thank the Americans for its revival. ... In England it is also known as the Antipodes.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1985
Source: Botanist at Bay
Author: SHERWOOD
Vol / Page: 18
Edition:
Quote: He also uses expressions like `down under', which implies implies that there's something wrong with the Southern Hemisphere, and `Australasia', which implies a close connection between New Zealand and her bullying barbaric neighbour, ...
Notes:

down-country
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:The flat part of a country (as opposed to hilly regions). The noun (and aj and av phrases) is used mainly to distinguish the lower or flat country (often the plains) from the high-country (South Island) or hill country (NI); it also often connotes `thecoast', `the town', as distinguished  from the back country (see also front country), as often New Zealand's flat land is coastal or towards the coast. The usage is US and`colonial'.
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: Compare front country. a. Esp. South Island, the country near the coast, or near town. 1932 Pyne, Gould and Guiness and Co's Report Down country, used (chiefly by people in the hills) to describe people or sheep.

Date: 0/0/1841

Vol / Page: 53
Edition: 1952
Quote: As we went on, the land became more and more barren and level, till it became a mere moor, without a shrub, and almost without vegetation; a few bushes of the miserable-looking Dracophyllum being all that occurred to break the monotony of the plain. <i>Ibid.</i> 100 I here first saw the great Dracophyllum; it formed a small tree about six inches in diameter, and twenty feet high; it is one of the most curious plants in the world; the leaves grow in tufts at the ends of the branches, just as in the dragon tree (Dracaena), and are the same shape, but in this species they are elegantly reflexed, like the feathers of a soldier's plume; they are a foot long and an inch broad at the base.

Notes:

Date: 14/10/1933
Source: Press, The
Author:
Vol / Page: 15
Edition:
Quote: Draft: (i) To divide stock into classes, either in a yard or  (cattle) by cutting out (q.v.). In the old days sheep were hand drafted, i.e. lifted over a rail or manhandled through agate. (Butler A First Year in Canterbury Settlement],p.135) About 1864 it was found possible to run sheep one at a time through a drafting race and move a single gate as they came, so drafting into two lots. See double gate. Cattle are usually now drafted in a stock-yard  (q.v.). See also shed. (G.P. W.) (ii) A number of stock sent for  sale, e.g. `The annual Stonyhurst draft of four-year-old ewes will be offered.' When the draft is actually offered it is usually spoken of as a line. ([1898 Morris Austral-English])
Notes: (Acland Gloss.)

Quote: drafting n. NZ & Austral. drawing off or selecting  livestock for particular purpose; drafting gate swing-gate at end of drafting race; drafting pen pen to hold selected animals; drafting race narrow alley down which animals are driven for drafting.
