Date: 0/0/1940
Source: Te Waimate
Author: STUDHOLME
Vol / Page: 136
Edition: 1954
Quote: In later years we had stockyards at different parts of the Station where the drafting was done. The cattle were driven up a narrow race, with double gates at the further end, which were worked by a man standing on a platform. These yards were specially built for handling wild cattle, and had narrow gaps between the hinge of the drafting gate and post, through which a man could escape from a charging beast.

Date: 0/0/1949
Source: High Country Days
Author: NEWTON
Vol / Page: 194
Edition:
Quote: DRAFTING: The main feature of sheepyards is the drafting race. This race, perhaps eight yards in length, is only wide enough for sheep to pass through in single file; at the end of the race are two swinging gates which can be manipulated to turn the sheep into different yards, and so separate them into different `lines' or mobs.

drafting yard
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:an enclosed yard into or out of which stock are drafted; also pl., the collection of pens, yards, races used esp. for handling stock.
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/0/1853
Source: Letter
Author: ALLOM
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  `I will conclude this part of the subject with a few words about stockyards. They are generally made of stout posts and rails; the corner posts ought to be much stronger than the rest, as they often have to bear the weight of a heavy bullock in branding and other operations. The yard is generally divided into three portions - viz., a large yard for the whole herd, a drafting yard, and a milking yard, at one end of which is placed the milking shed, cow bails, and calf house, the whole being so arranged that a calf can be let out to suck its mother on one side while she is being milked on the other.'
Notes: 1853 Allom letter in 1853 Earp NZ 123 (Wairarapa)

Halved and quartered, it was then levered ... on to greased rollers and rushed towards the big circulars, which turned it into flitches. Then the small circulars, the drag, and the goose completed its metamorphosis into the regulation strips ...

drag
Homonym Number: 5
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:in full drag ball
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/0/1876
Source: TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page: 8/179
Edition:
Quote: These tailings are treated in berdans with extra quicksilver andground up. The berdans now in use at the Thames ... are generally five feet in diameter ... At one time a couple of rotating balls were considered sufficient for the amount of crushing required; now, the general practice is to have a loose ball as well as a stationary one attached to a chain,and it is called a drag ball; this drag does more work than a loose ball ... for the drag grinds the bowl as much as the tailings.
Notes: (Goodall Thames Gold-fields)

drag hunt
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number: 1
Definition:a horseback hunt where the quarry is not live game, but a sack or sheepskin which has been impregnated with anise or a similar strong smell, dragged over the course.

Notes:

Date: 0/0/1989
Source: NZ English Newsletter
Author:
Vol / Page: 3/24
Edition:
Quote: dragging the chain: A shearer is said to do this when he lags behind the rest because he is slow, lazy or inexperienced. The origin is from bullock driving where it is said that the rear bullock attached by a chain to the wagon, `drags the chain' if it slows down.
Notes: (Wallace Shearing Glossary)

Author: BAINES
Vol / Page: 173
Edition:
Quote: Cross-cut saws have what is called a peg-tooth and cut both ways. It is a great improvement to sharpen every fifth tooth, counting from the centre to the ends, as a drag tooth, that is, a tooth filed square across and with a considerable hook, this arrangement tends to keep the cut clear of sawdust.

They were properly speaking a new species of dragon-trees, with broad leaves (dracaena australis) of which the central shoot when quite tender, tastes something like an almond's kernel, with a little of the flavour of cabbage.

Edition: 1952
Quote: I here first saw the great Dracophyllum; it formed a small tree about six inches in diameter, and twenty feet high; it is one of the most curious plants in the world; the leaves grow in tufts at the ends of the branches, just as in the dragon tree (Dracaena), and are the same shape, but in this species they are elegantly reflexed, like the feathers of a soldier's plume; they are a foot long and an inch broad at the base.

draw
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:also sliver, stringer.
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/0/1950
Source: Letter
Author: ROY GILBERD
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  [The fibres of wood in a tree just about to fall] do not part all in one plane and `stringers' or `drawers' are drawn out of the barrel, sometimes several feet long. Sometimes men on contract, trying to save timber, place their saw-cut too low and some of the wood-fibres break off up in the barrel. These are `stringers' while they are breaking, and `slivers' or `drawers' when they are left upright in the sloven.
Notes: (Northland)

Date: 0/0/1953
Source: Story of the Kauri, The
Author: REED
Vol / Page: 151
Edition:
Quote: A `draw' was a serious defect, but was not due to any fault in the living tree. When a tree fell before it was quite severed, it sometimes, in the act of falling, wrenched or `drew' out a portion of the butt, leaving great jagged, fang-like splinters adhering to the stump. The damage was, of course, always to the heart wood ... [<i>Ibid.</i> 156 [Edward Thompson] ... very often, before the saw got within a foot or so of the front scarf, the tree would start to fall gradually, and the uncut timber between the saw and the front scarf would have to break, and seldom cleanly; the heart, being more brittle than the sap, would break here and there, several feet above where thesawcut would have been standing straight. As the tree fell, these pieces, still attached to the stump, would draw out of the tree, and being almost heart-wood constituted the chief defect we call `draws'.
Notes: [?c1900]

draw a marble
Homonym Number:

dray
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:In NZ of two main types,(1) a high-platformed two-wheeled shafted single-horse-drawn cart with sides, often a `spring dray'; and (2) in early settlement, a bullock-dray-->, a usu. four-wheeled pole-wagon without sides (occas. draycart--> (OED2 1719) as in:

dregs
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:beer slops
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/0/1946
Source: AJHR
Author:
Vol / Page: H-38/113
Edition:
Quote: The word "dregs" refers to the drippings from the taps in a bar and to the overflow from the glasses as they are filled.  These dregs are sometimes called "swill".. or "slops". When they are mixed with beer for sale the resultant liquid is colloquially known as "Wompo". The term has been in use among barmen for as long as one experienced licensee could recollect - from twenty to thirty years.., and it is known to the man in the street. <i>Ibid.</i> 115 The resultant "Wompo" was then served to the public.

Date: 0/0/1978
Source: Gold Mining at Waihi
Author: McARA
Vol / Page: 184
Edition:
Quote: The term driving generally referred to tunnelling in any direction but in some circumstances, where reefs were present, it meant tunnelling along the line of the reef or parallel to it. The term drifting was used more specifically for driving on a reef, while the term crosscutting referredto tunnelling across the reef up to an angle of say forty-five degrees; however it was common to talk of `driving a crosscut'.

See:

Citations
Date: 19/10/1986
Source: NZ Times
Author:
Vol / Page: 3
Edition:
Quote: Included in Hodges's study is the truly macho battle of alcoholic consumption - the drinking game. ... There'll be some inane feat of manliness to perform, such as a lewd tongue-twister, ora physical show of strength, and he who loses has to down his glass in a gulp. In Otago alone, Hodges found 42 varieties of the theme, with names such as `One Fat Hen and a Couple of Ducks' or the `Hokonui Swindle'.

drive
Homonym Number: 1
Word Class:verb
Sense Number:2
Definition:to float (timber) down a river usually by releasing a dam. Also  drive out.
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/0/1874

Vol / Page: 170
Edition:

Notes:

Date: 0/0/1877
Source: TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page: 9/368
Edition:
Quote: The only other practical method I can propose for the preservation of timber is to `drive' the logs down to deep-water at once.
Notes: (Brown)

Date: 0/0/1889
Source: Forest Flora
Author: KIRK
Vol / Page: 151
Edition:
Quote:  ... the sluices of the dams are opened, and the logs, which are often piled high in the bed of the stream, are `driven' to the booms by the volume of water suddenly liberated.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1894
Source: NZ Official Yearbook
Author:
Vol / Page: 331
Edition:
Quote: Often it is necessary to construct costly dams to impound the water in the upper parts of the creek, in order that it may be suddenly liberated ... so that the entire assemblage [332] of [kauri] logs may be `driven' to the booms. In dry seasons the logs may remain in the bed of the creek for months, and, occasionally, after a successful `drive', the harvest of logs is carried out to sea and lost, through the booms breaking from the immense pressure behind them.
Notes: (T. Kirk)

Date: 0/0/1906
Source: Plants of NZ
Author: LAING & BLACKWELL
Vol / Page: 63
Edition:
Quote: Here [the kauri logs] lie until a `fresh' drives them down the creek or harbour where the `boom' lies waiting.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1913
Source: NZ Geol. Survey Bulletin
Author:
Vol / Page: No.16 (NS) 19
Edition:
Quote: The logs were transported to the mill in the case of the Waitanui by a wooden-railed tramway; in the case of the Tamaki they were `driven.'
Notes: (Henderson and Bartrum, Aroha and Hauraki)

Quote: As a rule, to drive a mob of sheep for any distance, takes not less than four hands ... <I>Ibid.</i>It needs incessant care to prevent stragglers breaking away from the head and sides of the mob, and the rear of the flock, made up of the weaker sheep, requires an equally constant lookout. The horses are led or ridden, as the ground allows; ... but in driving through unknown country, the halts are made very much where the explorers find themselves at sundown.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1949

Author: NEWTON
Vol / Page: 195
Edition: 1950
Quote: Drive: In very rough bluffy country it is sometimes possible to muster, or `drive,' deer into some  spot where they will be cornered or trapped, and a big kill can be made.

drive
Homonym Number: 2

Sense Number:
Definition:to fall a group of trees whose trunks have been partially cut through, and so placed that the impetus of falling a chosen one will set off a `chain reaction'. See drive n2..
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:

Citations
Date: 0/0/1899
Source: In the Shadow of the Bush
Author: BELL
Vol / Page: 83
Edition:
Quote: Harry had just given the last cut of the axe to a big rimu, which, after a far premonitory cracks as it began to move, fell, driving before it in its line of fall a dozen or so of the smaller trees, which had been `scarfed' or cut partly through in readiness, and skilfully, so that each, when struck, might again in its turn strike and bring down another. The noise of a fall or drive of this kind is like thunder - loud, prolonged, reverberating. <I>Ibid..</I> 94 Harry had planned a big drive with a combined rimu and rata ... had `scarfed' all the smaller trees in front of it down to the already felled bush, and expected, when it was brought down, that it would send to earth the whole of these, driving one upon another far beyond the reach of its own length ...

Date: 0/0/1986
Source: Off the Sheep's Back
Author: RICHARDS
Vol / Page: 22
Edition:
Quote: It was quite a common practice for experienced bushmen, to have a `drive'. If you are chopping up a `face' and there is a large tree behind you further up the face, you select that as the `key'. To save time ... you do not waste time by chopping down each tree individually, but just `scarf' and partly chop each tree. When all is ready and you have worked back to the key, you scarf it verycarefully. ... If everything goes according to plan it will `drive' the one below, which will in turn drive the next, and so on ...
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1955
Source: Land of My Children
Author: WILSON
Vol / Page: 11
Edition:
Quote: A `drive' was in progress; as the men do the underscrubbing they note the large trees and their distance from each other. They scarf each one so that it will fall on the next. Then, after all the smaller timber has been brought down, they fell the first tree which falls on the second and so starts a whole sequence of crashes. The line need not be straight. More often, it zig-zags from right to left. Bushmen can do wonders by means of an ingenious drive.
Notes:

On or near it a shaft was sunk ... but was not utilised for driving-out. ... Somewhere about 1880 ... others drove an inclined drift from point to the southward of the back lead for a distance of 254 feet ... Then they drove horizontally for a short distance and intersected an auriferous ... layer of quartz wash, about 10 feet wide, known as the `front lead'.
Notes: 1914 P.G. Morgan report  Geological Survey Branch 147 in 1962 Evans Waikaka Saga 4

Vol / Page: 331

Quote: Often it is necessary to construct costly dams to impound the water in the upper parts of the creek, in order that it may be suddenly liberated ... so that the entire assemblage [332] of [kauri] logs may be `driven' to the booms. In dry seasons the logs may remain in the bed of the creek for months, and, occasionally, after a successful `drive', the harvest of logs is carried out tosea and lost, through the booms breaking from the immense pressure behind them.
Notes: (T. Kirk)

Date: 0/0/1989
Source: NZ English Newsletter
Author:
Vol / Page: 3/24
Edition:
Quote: driver: A leather strap on hand shears. This fits firmly round the handle and over the back of the shearer's hand, thus allowing more drive to be given to a blow while preventing the hands from slipping over the blades. Sometimes this is also called the  `monkey'.
Notes: (Wallace Shearing Glossary)

Notes: 1914 P.G. Morgan report Geological Survey Branch 147 in 1962 Evans Waikaka Saga 4

Date: 0/0/1978
Source: Gold Mining at Waihi
Author: McARA
Vol / Page: 184
Edition:
Quote: The term driving generally referred to tunnelling in any direction but in some circumstances, where reefs were present, it meant tunnelling along the line of the reef or parallel to it. The term drifting was used more specifically for driving on a reef, while the term crosscutting referred totunnelling across the reef up to an angle of say forty-five degrees; however it was common to talk of `driving a crosscut'.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1985
Source: Botanist at Bay
Author: SHERWOOD
Vol / Page: 26
Edition:
Quote: The words flew, and enriched Celia's [an English visitor's] vocabulary. `Duck shoving' was the local name for buck-passing between government departments. A `Queen Street farmer' was a city slicker who owned land or stock for tax-fiddle reasons. `Skite' and `drongo' were terms ofabuse. A `cow-cockie' was a dairy farmer and inferior for some reason to a `runholder' concerned only with sheep. A `piker' was a faint-hearted person who gave up the fight too soon, ...
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1986
Source: Gemina
Author: MILLER
Vol / Page: 23
Edition:
Quote: Then there's those two drongoes. ... What's the bloody matter with them? Me I'd be into the flax bushes like a shot, ...

Date: 0/0/1988
Source: Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A
Author: McGILL
Vol / Page: 39
Edition:
Quote: drongo slow-witted person; probably early 1920s Australian recehorse of that name which never won, the horse most likely getting its name for the bird; eg `Gabe's a complete drongo when it comes to driving in rush-hour traffic, though otherwise he's competent enough.' NZA.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1989
Source: Pacific Way
Author:
Vol / Page: 10
Edition:
Quote: Suppose a friend says to me, `You know that drongo who was on the chain with me at the works last summer? Just a little joker he was, remember? A real serious ankle-biter. Hailed from somewhere down the Wire Wrapper. A right useless bastard. Couldn't see the road to the dunny if it had red flags on it. Well, it seems that he's shacked up with some pluty Remmers sheila and she's about to drop her bundle.' ... A non-New Zealander will probably require a translation, ... My friend is communicating to me the information that a slow-witted, incompetent person of diminutive stature, who was reared in the Wairarapa district and workedfor a time in the killing gang of an abattoir, is now cohabiting with a wealthy woman from the affluent Auckland suburb of Remuera. This woman is soon to give birth.
Notes: (Sharp New Zildish)

Quote: fromDROP as to drop a tree - to fell a tree - was missed by Turner but is good Aust as well as NZ colloquialism.Similarly too, KNOCK a crop down is to cut it.`THROW DOWN' is still a good colloquialism for reaping a crop. See the last line of Donne, Hymn to God My God ...
Notes:  J. Davey (Whangarei)

Date: 5/3/1981

Vol / Page: 28
Edition:

Date: 0/1/1989
Source: Pacific Way
Author:
Vol / Page: 10
Edition:
Quote: Suppose a friend says to me, `You know that drongo who was on the chain with me at the works last summer? Just a little joker he was, remember? A real serious ankle-biter. Hailed from somewhere down the Wire Wrapper. A right useless bastard. Couldn't see the road to the dunny if it had red flags on it. Well, it seems that he's shacked up with some pluty Remmers sheila and she's about to drop her bundle.' ... A non-New Zealander will probably require a translation, ... My friend is communicating to me the information that a slow-witted, incompetent person of diminutive stature, who was reared in the Wairarapa district and worked for a time in the killing gang of an abattoir, is now cohabiting with a wealthy woman from the affluent Auckland suburb of Remuera. This woman is soon to give birth.
Notes: (Sharp New Zildish)

dropper
Homonym Number: 2
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:2
Definition:a hotel worker who handed out illegal after-hour take-away liquor; a sly-grog scout.
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 28/10/1911
Source: NZ Truth
Author:
Vol / Page: 331/4/6
Edition:
Quote: It is possible to get as much liquor as one wants in Masterton, and while much of it (privately and legitimately brought in) is of good quality, much more (surreptitiously dispensed at sly-groggeries and by what are locally termed `droppers' at enhanced prices) is atrocious and harmful liquor. ...A Masterton gentleman ... told our representative that the knew of twenty sly-groggeries in Masterton, and double that number of `droppers.' It can be imagined what kind of poison they dispense.

drummer
Homonym Number: 1
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:the slowest (often the learner) shearer in a gang
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 7/7/1911
Source: Maoriland Worker
Author:
Vol / Page: 18/14/2
Edition:
Quote: The `drummer,' starting from the man who carried a drum, became the man who carried a swag and (then or thereafter) the loaded man (as a commercial traveller loaded with samples). To `carry the load' is another synonym; and the essential point throughout the symbolry was evidently the load.  ... and a `drummer' is the man with the lowest tally - perhaps because he is likeliest to take and keep the track with his `load.' The general applications of these fresh significations may be doubted.
Notes:

Date: 20/1/1934
Source: Press, The
Author:
Vol / Page: 15
Edition:
Quote: Drummer.-The slowest shearer in a shed.

Author:
Vol / Page: 3/24
Edition:
Quote: drummer: The name given to the shearer with the lowest daily tally. He is not necessarily a bad or lazy shearer, but simply slower than the rest, and in a group of good shearers he could be quite competent, but not as good as the others.
Notes: (Wallace Shearing Glossary)

dry diggings
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/0/1867
Source: New Zealand (Hochstetter)
Author: HOCHSTETTER
Vol / Page: 104
Edition:
Quote: The conglomerates accumulated on the slopes of the mountains are the proper field for the "dry diggings", while from the gravel and sand streams the gold is obtained by "wet diggings".
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1864
Source: Geology NZ
Author: HOCHSTETTER & PETERMAN
Vol / Page: 88
Edition:
Quote: By the gradual wearing away of these rocks ... large masses of debris have been formed, and nature itself has executed an operation of gold-washing, by collecting the heavier particles and depositing them in the gullies of streams, or in the conglomerates covering the slopes of the hills.  There are, therefore, two principal descriptions of diggings; either `river diggings', in the beds of streams, or `dry diggings', in the conglomerate and gravel accumulated on the slopes of the mountains.
Notes:

Dry Valley
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/0/1975
Source: Footprints on a Frozen Continent
Author: McPHERSON
Vol / Page: 64
Edition: 1979
Quote: Transecting the Transantarctic Mountains west of McMurdo Sound are three ice and snow-free valleys collectively called the Dry Valleys. The valleys extend from the 2,750 m Polar Plateau in the west to within a short distance of the sea. Along with some smaller subsidiary valleys the system constitutes the largest ice-free area in Antarctica, a total of approximately 4,000 square km.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1975
Source: Footprints on a Frozen Continent
Author: McPHERSON
Vol / Page: 85
Edition: 1979
Quote: The Dry Valley Region is a geologist's paradise because of the excellent exposure of rock, without grass, trees, soil or snow, to hide it.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1969
Source: AJHR
Author:
Vol / Page: H34 : 65
Edition:
Quote: Throughout the summer Vanda Station proved its value as a staging station for parties operating within the Dry Valley region... Apart from making measurements throughout the year of the climate of this unique "Dry Valley" area and of the "hot" lake near the station, the wintering-over party also carry out upper atmosphere physics and earthquake observations in conjunction with Scott Base.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1988
Source: Icebound
Author: KNIGHT
Vol / Page: 113
Edition:
Quote: Frighteningly, as this book was going to press, newspapers in New Zealand reported a significant rise in Lake Vanda, in the Dry Valley region of the Ross Dependency.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1978
Source: NZ Antarctic Record
Author:
Vol / Page: 1(1) : 15
Edition:
Quote: There are three main Dry Valleys, the Victoria Valley in the north, the Taylor Valley in the south and the Wright Valley in the west. Together these three valley systems expose 4000 km2 of moraines, sediments and rocks - an oasis on the edge of the ice sheet.
Notes:

Date: 0/3/1970
Source: Antarctic
Author:
Vol / Page: 5(9) : 371
Edition:
Quote: The Dry Valleys were originally discovered in 1903 by Scott, Evans and Lashly and since the rediscovery by geologists Peter Webb and Barrie McKelvey in 1957, the work of summer field parties, including geologists, chemists and physicists, led to the decision to winter at Vanda Station.
Notes:

dry-chucker-in
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/0/1985
Source: Woolscours of NZ
Author: BREMNER
Vol / Page: 15
Edition:
Quote: A description of an unidentified sheepstation in 1881 recorded that a twenty-two man gang ... put through [the sheep-wash] 1250 sheep in a ... day. The `yarder-up' kept the pen nearest the wash full of sheep. Two `dry-chuckers-in' forced sheep through a swing door where they fell four feet into a 20-foot wooden trough full of hot soapy water. ... The trough was divided into four partitions with a `crutcher' at each. Four times each sheep was soaped, its back scrubbed with a crutch. ... At the end of the trough three `wet-chuckers-in' hauled frightened sheep out and sent them down three slides to the cold-water rinsing wells. Each well had two spouts of cold water and four hands called `spouters' who tilted the sheep, parting the wool
Notes: 1881

dry-cow therapy
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number: 1
Definition:a treatment of newly dried off cows with a long term slow acting antibiotic to prevent mastitis.
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:Rural
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 23/2/1978
Source: NZ Farmer
Author:
Vol / Page: 17
Edition:
Quote: The objects of dry cow therapy are 1) to eliminate existing infections of the udder 2) to prevent new infections during the dry period. Dry cow therapy helps protect the cow against these new infections because antibiotics are present in the udder for many weeks.
Notes:

Date: 29/4/1980
Source: NZ Dairy Exporter
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote: A warning against farmers expecting 100 per cent results from dry cow therapy can be a valuable tool against mastitis. The Wallaceville researchers said that dry cow therapy was unable to eliminate all infections or prevent reinfection or new infection during the dry period.

Drysdale

Author: BROOKING
Vol / Page: 87
Edition:
Quote: Much of the credit for producing the Drysdale breed must go to its original ancestor the Neilson ram lamb named "Pa Neilson", which... had such a hairy coat that Dry had to invent another category which he named the "N"-grade in honour of its owner.
Notes:

Date: 25/10/2002
Source: Dominion Post
Author:
Vol / Page: C6
Edition:
Quote: He cites the example of the Drysdale sheep, a wool breed developed in the 1950 for the carpet industry, that has now virtually disappeared from New Zealand farms.
Notes:

Date: 17/7/1979
Source: Dominion
Author:
Vol / Page: 5/1
Edition:
Quote: The man who developed the Drysdale sheep breed, Dr Francis William Dry has died in Palmerston North. He was [87 years old.] Dr Dye was born in Driffield, Yorkshire, and educated at Bridlington School and Leeds University from which he graduated in 1925 as a Doctor of Science. He came to New Zealand in 1929 to be a lecturer at the newly-founded Massey Agricultural College. Shortly after his arrival Dr Dry discovered a ram lamb in a flock near Palmerston North which had an extremely hairy fleece due to an abundance of halo-hairs. Dr Dry's successful efforts to isolate the gene in Romney led to the development of the Drysdale. Dr Dry devoted nearly 40 years studying the genetic makeup of the fleece of the sheep and published many papers. He retired from Massey University in 1956 as Professor of Animal Genetics but continued his interest in the Drysdale till his death.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1986
Source: NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary
Author:
Vol / Page: 231
Edition:
Quote: Drysdale n. NZ breed of sheep developed from Romneys and Cheviots yielding wool which when blended with crossbred wool is suitable  for carpet making. [F.W. Dry, agricultural scientist]

dub
Homonym Number: 3
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:Often pl. Cheap clay marbles, esp. ones put down to be fired at; a marble game or action where marbles are laid down, usu. in a ring, to be fired at. Compare also dub in (marbles). [cf also:
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/0/1972
Source: Folkgames of Children
Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Vol / Page: 174
Edition:
Quote: Marbles had a language of its own. There were names for the marbles, the games, and all the various aspects of the play. There were terms for marbles such as `taw' or `shooter', referring to the marbles used to fire with; `dubs', `dates', `stakes', `dukes', or `changers', referring to the marbles put down to be fired at. [175] Here is Little Ring as played in Waitara, Taranaki, in 1899: A team would consist of six to eight boys [order of shooting determined] ... An oval ring was decribed in the earth by means of a stick, and each player would `dub in' one marble ... A line was drawn some six or eight feet away, as the firing line, and the first player sang out `Fire!' as he fired the first shot.]
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1953
Source: Unorganized Games
Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Vol / Page: 2/770
Edition:
Quote: It is important to distinguish these `Action-Terms' of marbles from the innumerable merely descriptive marble terms which have no effect on the course of the action - terms such asRinger, In, Smug, Dead Stick, Skun, Skinned, Sported off, Scat, Cannons, Dubs, Kills, Funs, Keeps, Pink.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1981
Source: History of Children's Play
Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Vol / Page: 269
Edition:
Quote: Here are some [marble] terms from Taranaki around 1880-1890: firsts, lay-up, stakes, tips, sticking-taw, nothings, anythings, fade-it, knuckledown stiff, dubs, finking [sic, ?funking], sips, spanning, placing; and from Dunedin School in 1949: knee high, manyies, tracks, screws, nuts, sleets, kills, forces, dig, dubs, cheats. (child marble-players')

One of the cockers gave my father a beautiful white cock, his comb dubbed, trimmed and fighting fit.

Author: 1/80
Vol / Page: 1960
Edition:
Quote:  [The Waikato] runs through ... deep fern fringed with raupo (a bullrush) ...[sic] and the magnificent toi-toi, a gigantic grass whose flower stalk is from 8 to 12 feet and has an exquisite feather of two feet long playing in every air. This grass is ... with the phormium tenax the most remarkable of the open country vegetable products. ... You see many nativedwellings & many canoes for they are a most locomotive people, few as ignorant of all but their own kainga as our British Hodge. There are troops of wild ducks & shags, some hawks of large size, bitterns & smaller waterfowl unknown to me.
Notes: (J.C. Richmond)

Vol / Page: 117

Quote:  `There are eleven species of Native Ducks belonging to nine genera, all found elsewhere, except two--the little Flightless Duck  of the Auckland Islands (genus <i>Nesonetta</i>) and the Blue  Mountain Duck (<i>Hymenolaemus</i>). Among the most interesting of the non-endemic forms, are the Paradise Duck or Sheldrake  (<i>Casarca variegata</i>), the Brown Duck (<i>Anas chlorotis</i>),  the Shoveller or Spoonbill duck (<i>Rhynchaspis variegata</i>), and the Scaup or Black Teal (<i>Fuligula Novae-Zealandiae</i>).']
Notes: [Morris]

duckstone
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:2
Definition:
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/0/1972
Source: Folkgames of Children
Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Vol / Page: 166
Edition:
Quote: A game that was based directly upon children's  interest in throwing stones was Duckstones (K-16). ... In the simplest form, the players put one stone on top of a larger stone and then attempted to knock the top one off by throwing other stones at it. The player who knocked off the most stones won. ... (South Clutha, 1875; Stillwater, Nelson, 1885; Wakefield, Nelson, 1875). <i>Ibid.</i> 167  In this [West Coast version of Duckstones] the duckstone belonged to the He. As soon as he put his duckstone on the big stone the game commenced and the others began to fire their own `dubs' at the duckstone.
Notes:

Date: 18/3/2000
Source: Listener (New Zealand Listener)
Author:
Vol / Page: 54
Edition:
Quote: While presenting a programme on Radio Sport recently, I asked listeners what a "dudapper" was... Eventually, one caller came up with the correct answer : a dudapper was once the term used to describe a delivery that bounced twice before reaching the batsman. Shortly after, an elderly gentleman rang in to say that when he was a youngster playing school cricket in England, a team-mate by the name of Nipper Dingle made a specialty of such a delivery. I distinctly remember," said the caller, " our master taking us for practices and saying, 'I've never seen a boy who could bowl a dudapper like you, Nipper Dingle.'"

Vol / Page: 99
Edition:
Quote: ... our claim proved a `duffer'. No less than fifteen shafts did we sink ..., but found a prospect of nothing sufficient to encourage us in working it. <I>Ibid.</i> 121 [Prospective diggers] had only arrived to find the whole thing what  is called in digging parlance a `duffer' - i.e., that there was comparatively `nothing' to repay them for even the trouble of digging a single hole.

Date: 0/0/1958
Source: Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn)
Author:
Vol / Page: 133
Edition: 8th
Quote: duffer 1. Useless or stupid person. 2. In Australia and New Zealand, a worked-out orunprofitable mine.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1962
Source: West Coast Gold Rushes
Author: MAY
Vol / Page: 526
Edition: 1967
Quote: DUFFER: applied to a rush, a shaft, or a claim generally. A failure. Synonyms were `shicer',`stringer' or, in the case of a false rush, `store-keepers' rush'. A claim which was exhausted was said to be `duffered out'. At Ross in 1866 putting down a duffer shaft was termed `sinking for the Queen'. Duffers (Creek) is a common West Coast place-name.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1974
Source: Bright Fine Gold
Author: HAY
Vol / Page: 200
Edition:
Quote: A duffer: No gold. ...CLAIMS Worthless claims or ground were called schicers or duffers. Those yielding up to [pounds]3 per week per man were known as `tucker' claims; up to [pounds]8 per week were known as `wages' claims; above [pounds]8 were known as `pilers'; the richest of all were known as `Home-ward-bounders.'
Notes:  (Glossary of Mining Terms)

Date: 0/0/1983
Source: Gold Fossicker's Handbook
Author: NOLAN
Vol / Page: 112
Edition:
Quote: Duffer: a mine, claim or gold-rush which proves worthless.
Notes: (gloss)

Date: 0/0/1982
Source: Collins Concise English Dictionary
Author:
Vol / Page: 344
Edition:
Quote: duffer ... 3. Austral. sl. a. a mine that proves  unproductive. b. a person who steals cattle.
Notes: [1986 NZPOD 232]

Date: 0/0/1863
Source: AJHR
Author:
Vol / Page: D6-3
Edition:
Quote: ... the place was `rushed' by about 500 men, who speedily deserted it, and declared the Waitahuna to be a `duffer.'
Notes: also in 1887 Handbook NZ Mines 5

Date: 0/0/1887
Source: Taken In
Author: HOPEFUL
Vol / Page: 135
Edition:
Quote: If a man isn't `up to the mark' he is called `a regular shicer!' This phrase originated from the gold diggings. Supposing a man is digging, but without success, andhe therefore abandons his hole, it is called a `shicer' - that is, the ground was called a `shicer' or duffer, thus the origin.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1889
Source: Lay of the Old Identities, The
Author: BLAIR
Vol / Page: 48
Edition:
Quote: He puddled and cradled, and digged all he knew / When the claim proved a regular duffer.
Notes:

Author:
Vol / Page: 66

Quote: It was soon found to be a "duffer" rush.

Vol / Page: 526
Edition: 1967
Quote: DUFFER: applied to a rush, a shaft, or a claim generally. A failure. Synonyms were `shicer', `stringer' or, in the case of a false rush, `store-keepers' rush'. A claim which was exhausted was said to be `duffered out'. At Ross in 1866 putting down a duffer shaft was termed `sinking for the Queen'. Duffers (Creek) is a common West Coast place-name.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1952
Source: Faring South
Author: LYON
Vol / Page: 194
Edition:
Quote: When shearers are striving for a tally, or a big output of shorn sheep, dumping is the act of pushing the lamb's head downward when seated on the boards, in such a way that the lamb'slungs are pushed down on his diaphragm causing great agony and often fatal injury ... . The idea is that by dumping the sides of the lamb are flattened and permit a larger flat surface of fleece to be exposed to the shears.
Notes:

Quote: Pay rise for drivers of dumpters [Headline]  The Government Railways Industrial Tribunal hasgranted a rise of 1 1/2d and hour, bringing the rate to 8/5 1/2, for dumpter drivers employed by the New Zealand Railways. The award was made in a reserved decision on a claim by the Amalgamated Society of Railway Servants for dumpter operators to be included with plant operators (employees with approved certificates) and paid at the rate of 8/8 1/2 and hour. Dumpter operators have been paid as lorry drivers at 8/4 per hour. (wool)

dung-duster
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:a topdressing pilot
Origin:[none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/0/1983
Source: Topdressers, The
Author: GREEN
Vol / Page: 141
Edition:
Quote: "Chris" Christoffells, the engineer at Rotorua, painted a typically English pub sign, <i>The Dung Duster's Arms</i>", and this hung in a prominent place behind the bar. <i>Ibid</i> 315 In the days when topdressing meant tiger moths many farmers were critical of how the fertiliser spread on the ground. They saw the superphosphate dust fall from the aircraft but it quickly settled on the grass and vanished from sight. A few pilots were astute enough to see the sprinkling of superphosphate on the cow dung in the paddocks. The farmers were called over to admire the dusting. So naturally topdressing pilots became "dung busters."

dunite
Homonym Number:
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:a mineral from Mt Dun in Nelson; a NZ mineral, a kind of olivine
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/0/1867
Source: New Zealand (Hochstetter)
Author: HOCHSTETTER
Vol / Page: 474
Edition:
Quote: [Dun Mountain, Nelson] consists of a very peculiar kind of rock, of a yellowish-green colour when recently broken, but turning rusty-brown on the surface when decomposing. The mass of the rock is olivine ...; it is distinguished from serpentine for which it was formerly taken, especially by its greater hardness, and its crystalline structure. I have called it Dunite.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1883
Source: Handbook of New Zealand
Author: HECTOR
Vol / Page: 56
Edition:
Quote: Chrome ore. This ore, which is a mixture of chromic iron and alumina, is chiefly associated with magnesian rock, resembling olivine in composition, named Dunite by Dr. Hochstetter.'
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1883
Source: TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page: 15/392
Edition:
Quote: This mineral is a massive variety of olivine through which grains of chromite are scattered. A specimen from the Dun Mountain, Nelson, was first described by Dr V. Hochstetter (New Zealand), 1863, Eng ed, p475) ...

Vol / Page: 43/451
Edition:
Quote: The less important [is] ... near the celebrated Milford Sound, in Fiordland. This locality is remarkable owing to the presence with the platinum of that peculiar nickel-iron mineral awaruite. In appearance it is not unlike platinum, and was mistaken by the miners for that mineral. ... Both the metal and the awaruite occur in a district composed ... of serpentine and dunite.

dust
Homonym Number: 2
Word Class:noun
Sense Number:
Definition:the dust, miners' phthisis or silicosis.
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain:[none]
Region:[none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date: 0/0/1978
Source: Gold Mining at Waihi (Glossary)
Author: McARA
Vol / Page: 320
Edition:
Quote: Dust: Quartz dust was a major menace to the health of miners. It blocked up the microscopic air-sacs in the lungs, producing hardening of the tissues and impairing the function of the lungs. Eventually, sometimes after many years, death resulted. The disease miners' phthisis was commonly called `the dust.' It gradually came to an end after the indroduction of axial-water-feed drills.
Notes:

Edition:
Quote:  ... it is no doubt also responsible for the dark coloured varnishes produced from the chip grades. [fn] The terms dust, seeds, chips, nubs, &c., are the names given to certain of the lower kauri gum grades according to the relative sizes of the pieces. From `dust' the size of the fragments increases in the order given, as does also the purity of the grade. Chalk, or `chalky gum,' is a particular grade recovered from swampy country and is characterized by its white or chalky appearance and large water content.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1966
Source: Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An
Author: McLINTOCK
Vol / Page: 2/207
Edition:
Quote: An increasing demand for poorer grades of gum [after 1900], used in making linoleum, made it profitable to search for smaller gum: `nuts', `chips', `seeds', and `dust'.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1972
Source: Gumdiggers, The
Author: REED
Vol / Page: 82
Edition:
Quote: The [1920 Kauri Gum Industry] report stated that during the preceding few years the proportion of low-grade gum, chips and dust (scrapings) had increased in volume ... to about two-thirds of the total gum exports.
Notes:

Date: 0/0/1982
Source: Where it all Began
Author: MALCOLM
Vol / Page: 110
Edition:
Quote: The scrapings [sc. of gum] were kept and sold as 'dust', the bigger pieces were known as 'nuts' and the biggest as 'bold'.
Notes:

Date: 0/4/1991
Source: NZ Geographic
Author:
Vol / Page: 41
Edition:
Quote: In order of decreasing size, the pieces of gum were known as nuggets, nubs, peas, chips, and dust.
Notes: check whether "nuts" or "nubs"
